SECTION: ANCESTOR: Sami
Source: core-lore/ancestors/sami.md
════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════

# Sami

## Cultural Significance

**Figures Associated:**
- Sámi people; Indigenous Finno-Ugric people native to Sápmi (northern Norway, Sweden, Finland, and Russia). Traditionally reindeer herders, their culture includes 10 distinct languages, joik (traditional singing), and duodji (crafts).

**Events Associated / Significant Cultural Impact:**
1. Riddu Riddu; an annual international Indigenous festival in northern Norway celebrating Sámi and global Indigenous cultures through music, dance, art, and performances — a vital space for reconnecting with heritage and shamanic practices.

2. Sámi traditional healing; rooted in holistic connection to nature, these practices include herbal remedies, rituals, and spiritual healing led by noaides (shamans), with knowledge passed orally despite suppression by colonization and Christianization.

3. The sacred bear cult; bears were revered as embodying strength and spiritual connection, with complex rituals surrounding their hunt, ceremonial feasting, and burial to honor the bear's spirit and ensure its rebirth.

**Fashion Icons / Symbolism:** Sámi hat,

Drugs Representations / Associated

## Drug Connections

**Modern:** [Psilacetin](../../drugs-detailed/psilacetin.md)

**Ancient:** [Mushrooms](../../drugs-detailed/mushrooms.md)

## Sources

- https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/S%C3%A1mi_people
- https://www.religiousstudiesproject.com/response/sami-shamanism-up-close-and-personal-by-marianne-vigdis-henriksen/
- https://icmagazine.org/medicines-land-sami-reflections-role-use-indigenous-medicine-today/
- https://www.laits.utexas.edu/sami/diehtu/siida/religion/bear.htm

SECTION: ANCESTOR: Satanist

════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════

# Satanist

> **1/1 Grail**: [Satanist Grail (#8557)](../../grails/satanist.md)

## Cultural Significance

**Figures Associated:**
- Jayne Mansfield; Hollywood actress rumored in the documentary "Mansfield 66/67" to have connections to Anton LaVey, with speculation that a satanic curse caused her 1967 car crash death.

- Anton LaVey; founder of the Church of Satan in 1966, author of "The Satanic Bible," who codified Satanism as a philosophy of individualism rather than devil worship.

**Events Associated / Significant Cultural Impact:**
1. The founding of the Church of Satan (1966); Anton LaVey established the first organized Satanic religion in San Francisco, codifying Satanism as a philosophy of individualism, carnality, and skepticism rather than literal devil worship.

2. The Satanic Panic (1980s-90s); a moral panic swept the US claiming widespread Satanic ritual abuse, despite no evidence. This hysteria led to false imprisonments and revealed society's fear of counterculture and non-Christian spirituality.

**Fashion Icons / Symbolism:** Pentagram, Baphomet, devil horns, cape, black robes, inverted cross, Sigil of Baphomet

Drugs Representations / Associated

## Drug Connections

**Modern:** [Clear Pill](../../drugs-detailed/clear-pill.md)

**Ancient:** [Ethanol](../../drugs-detailed/ethanol.md)

## Sources

- https://www.vanityfair.com/hollywood/2017/10/jayne-mansfield-death-satan-documentary
- https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Church_of_Satan
- https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Satanic_panic

<!-- @generated:backlinks-start -->

SECTION: ANCESTOR: Sicanje
Source: core-lore/ancestors/sicanje.md
════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════

# Sicanje

## Cultural Significance

**Figures Associated:**
- Catholic Croat girls and women; it was a cultural and religious tradition for spiritual protection or identity. Some Albanian and Vlach women in the western Balkans also practiced it historically.

**Events Associated / Significant Cultural Impact:**
1. The Sicanje Project; a Cleveland State University documentation effort preserving the traditional tattooing practice through 24 interviews conducted in 2019 in Bosnia. Led by Marija Maracic and Josipa Karaca, it records oral histories of women who received tattoos as girls around Saint Joseph's feast day for protective purposes.

**Fashion Icons / Symbolism:** Sicanje Tattoo,

Drugs Representations / Associated

## Drug Connections

**Modern:** [Alcohol](../../drugs-detailed/alcohol.md)

**Ancient:** [Ethanol](../../drugs-detailed/ethanol.md)

## Sources

- https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sicanje
- https://www.atlasobscura.com/articles/sicanje-traditional-balkan-tattoo
- https://engagedscholarship.csuohio.edu/sicanje/

════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════
SECTION: ANCESTOR: Stonewall
Source: core-lore/ancestors/stonewall.md
════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════

# Stonewall

## Cultural Significance

**Figures Associated:**
- Marsha P. Johnson; Black trans activist and self-identified drag queen who was at the forefront of the Stonewall uprising. She co-founded STAR (Street Transvestite Action Revolutionaries) with Sylvia Rivera to support homeless trans youth.

- Sylvia Rivera; Latina trans activist who fought alongside Marsha P. Johnson and continued advocating for trans rights until her death in 2002. Often erased from mainstream LGBTQ+ narratives, she represents the radical roots of queer liberation.

**Events Associated / Significant Cultural Impact:**
1. The Stonewall Uprising (June 28, 1969); when police raided the Stonewall Inn, patrons — led by trans women of color, drag queens, and butch lesbians — fought back. Six days of protests followed, sparking the modern LGBTQ+ rights movement.

2. The first Pride marches (1970); on the one-year anniversary of Stonewall, the first Gay Pride marches were held in New York, Los Angeles, San Francisco, and Chicago. What began as protest became the global Pride tradition.

**Fashion Icons / Symbolism:** Stonewall shirt, rainbow flag (created 1978), liberation buttons, protest signs, leather and denim

Drugs Representations / Associated

## Drug Connections

**Modern:** [Poppers](../../drugs-detailed/poppers.md), [Alcohol](../../drugs-detailed/alcohol.md)

**Ancient:** [Ethanol](../../drugs-detailed/ethanol.md)

## Sources

- https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stonewall_riots
- https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marsha_P._Johnson
- https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sylvia_Rivera

<!-- @generated:backlinks-start -->

Source: core-lore/ancestors/sufis.md
════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════

# Sufis

## Cultural Significance

**Figures Associated:**

**Events Associated / Significant Cultural Impact:**
1. Sufi Dervish Whirling; the "whirling dervishes" practice meditative spinning as zikr (remembrance of God), founded by followers of the 13th-century mystic Rumi in Konya, Turkey. Spinning symbolizes planets orbiting the sun, with one hand raised to receive divine energy and the other lowered to channel it to earth.

2. The poetry of Rumi; Jalal ad-Din Muhammad Rumi became the best-selling poet in America centuries after his death. His mystical verses on love, union with the divine, and the soul's journey transcend religious boundaries.

**Fashion Icons / Symbolism:** Robe, traditional sufi hat, beads, niqab

Drugs Representations / Associated

## Drug Connections

**Modern:** [Iproniazid](../../drugs-detailed/iproniazid.md)

**Ancient:** [Syrian Rue](../../drugs-detailed/syrian-rue.md)

## Sources

- https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sufi_whirling

<!-- @generated:backlinks-start -->
## Miberas with this Ancestor

SECTION: ANCESTOR: Thai
Source: core-lore/ancestors/thai.md
════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════

# Thai

## Cultural Significance

**Figures Associated:**
- Paradorn Srichaphan; pioneering Thai tennis player who broke into the world top 10 in the early 2000s, inspiring a generation of Southeast Asian athletes and representing Thai excellence on the global stage.

- Apichatpong Weerasethakul; visionary Thai filmmaker whose dreamlike, spiritually-infused cinema won the Palme d'Or at Cannes. His work explores memory, rural Thailand, and the boundaries between waking life and the spirit world.

**Events Associated / Significant Cultural Impact:**
1. Thailand's Full Moon Party; originating on Koh Phangan in the late 1980s, this monthly beach rave became a pilgrimage site for global party culture, blending trance music, psychedelic culture, and Thai hospitality into an iconic countercultural event.

2. The Thai Ladyboy (Kathoey) tradition; Thailand's long-standing acceptance of gender fluidity predates Western LGBTQ+ movements. Kathoey have been part of Thai culture for centuries, appearing in folklore and finding spaces in entertainment, beauty pageants, and daily life.

**Fashion Icons / Symbolism:** Thai silk patterns, elephant motifs, Buddhist amulets, flower garlands

Drugs Representations / Associated

## Drug Connections

**Modern:** [Estrogen](../../drugs-detailed/estrogen.md), [Kratom](../../drugs-detailed/kratom.md)

**Ancient:** [Kwao Krua](../../drugs-detailed/kwao-krua.md), [Sakae Na](../../drugs-detailed/sakae-na.md)

## Sources

- https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Full_Moon_Party
- https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Apichatpong_Weerasethakul

SECTION: ANCESTOR: Turkey
Source: core-lore/ancestors/turkey.md
════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════

# Turkey

## Cultural Significance

**Figures Associated:**
- Barış Manço; legendary Turkish rock musician who blended Anatolian folk with psychedelic rock in the 1970s. His flamboyant style and TV show made him a beloved national icon.

- Göbekli Tepe builders; the unknown people who constructed the world's oldest known temple complex around 9500 BCE in southeastern Turkey, predating Stonehenge by 6,000 years and rewriting human prehistory.

**Events Associated / Significant Cultural Impact:**
1. Turkish Hammam culture; the Ottoman bathhouse tradition blending Roman, Byzantine, and Islamic bathing practices. Hammams served as social centers for cleansing, relaxation, and community gathering — a tradition that influenced spas worldwide.

2. The Psychedelic Anatolian Rock scene; in the 1960s-70s, Turkish musicians fused Western rock with traditional Anatolian scales and instruments like the saz. Banned and suppressed after the 1980 military coup, this music is now rediscovered globally.

**Fashion Icons / Symbolism:** Star Crescent symbol, Ottoman Tughra, evil eye (nazar), tulip motifs, Turkish carpet patterns

Drugs Representations / Associated

## Drug Connections

**Modern:** [Ketamine](../../drugs-detailed/ketamine.md)

**Ancient:** [Grayanotoxin](../../drugs-detailed/grayanotoxin.md)

## Sources

- https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bar%C4%B1%C5%9F_Man%C3%A7o
- https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/G%C3%B6bekli_Tepe
- https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Anatolian_rock

SECTION: DRUG: 2C B
Source: drugs-detailed/2c-b.md
════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════

# 2C-B

## Effects & Properties

**Effects:** Depending on the dose, the drug can induce altered perceptions,
vivid visual hallucinations, heightened emotional states, changes in thought patterns and a mild
distortion of time. It can also cause euphoria, increased sociability and introspective or
dissociative experiences.

**Natural Occurrence:** 2C-B does not occur in nature, it is a
synthetic compound created through chemical synthesis, derived from phenylethylamine
precursors with bromine and methoxy groups added to the aromatic ring.

## History

2C-B was first synthesized by Alexander Shulgin in 1974 and documented in his landmark book PiHKAL (1991), where he described it as one of his most important creations. It was briefly sold legally in the US as a therapeutic aid and aphrodisiac under the name "Nexus" before being classified as a Schedule I substance in 1995. 2C-B became a popular club and rave drug in Europe and South America from the late 1990s onward, valued for its unique blend of mild psychedelic visuals and empathogenic warmth at moderate doses.

## Connections

**Archetype:** [Freetekno](../core-lore/archetypes.md#freetekno)

**Ancestor:** [Native American](../core-lore/ancestors/native-american.md)

**Tarot Card:** [Queen of Cups](../core-lore/tarot-cards/queen-of-cups.md)

**Paired With:** [Peyote](peyote.md)

## Sources

- https://www.erowid.org/chemicals/2cb/2cb.shtml
- https://nida.nih.gov/research-topics/psychedelic-dissociative-drugs
- [2C-B - Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2C-B)
- [Alexander Shulgin - Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alexander_Shulgin)
- [PiHKAL - Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/PiHKAL)
- [2C-B | C10H14BrNO2 - PubChem](https://pubchem.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/compound/Bromodimethoxyphenethylamine)
- [2C or Not 2C: Phenethylamine Designer Drug Review - PMC](https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC3657019/)

════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════
SECTION: DRUG: Acacia
Source: drugs-detailed/acacia.md
════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════

# Acacia

## Effects & Properties

**Effects:** Vivid visual and auditory hallucinations, altered sense of time and
reality, euphoria, and profound spiritual or mystical experiences. Physically it can increase heart
rate and blood pressure, pupil dilation, and in some cases nausea. In higher doses or
unprepared settings can cause anxiety, panic, or disorientation.

**Natural Occurrence:** In plants, DMT likely serves as a defense
against herbivores or pathogens. In humans its endogenous presence is under study with
theories linking it to dreaming, near-death experiences, or spiritual phenomena (speculative).

**- Plants:** Found in numerous plant species, particularly those used in traditional
psychoactive preparations, such as Psychotria viridis (chacruna), Banisteriopsis caapi,
Mimosa tenuiflora, and Acacia species. It is present in leaves, bark, or roots, often in low
concentrations.

**- Animals:** Trace amounts are detected in the brain, blood, and urine of mammals,
including humans.

**- Fungi and Toads:** Present in some fungi (Psilocybe species, etc) and certain toad
venoms.
**Appearance:** DMT is not visible in plants or
animals but is extracted as a powder or resin from plant material (Mimosa tenuiflora root bark
yields a reddish-brown extract, in Ayahuasca it is part of a dark, bitter liquid brew).

## History

DMT-containing Acacia species have been used by Aboriginal Australians for thousands of years, particularly Acacia acuminata and Acacia obtusifolia, which feature in traditional medicine and possibly ceremonial practices. The ancient Egyptians also revered Acacia nilotica as a sacred tree, and some researchers have speculated that DMT-containing Acacia species may have played a role in ancient Near Eastern religious experiences, including the biblical burning bush narrative. In the modern era, Australian Acacia species became significant to the global psychedelic community from the 1990s onward as sources of extracted DMT for ayahuasca analogs ("acaciahuasca").

## Connections

**Archetype:** [Acidhouse](../core-lore/archetypes.md#acidhouse)

**Ancestor:** [Aboriginal](../core-lore/ancestors/aboriginal.md)

**Tarot Card:** [Eight of Swords](../core-lore/tarot-cards/eight-of-swords.md)

**Paired With:** [DMT](dmt.md)

## Sources

- https://www.erowid.org/chemicals/dmt/dmt.shtml
- https://erowid.org/chemicals/dmt/dmt_info2.shtml
- https://pubchem.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/compound/N_N-Dimethyltryptamine
- [N,N-Dimethyltryptamine - Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/N,N-Dimethyltryptamine)
- [List of Acacia species known to contain psychoactive alkaloids - Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_Acacia_species_known_to_contain_psychoactive_alkaloids)
- [Acacia obtusifolia - Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Acacia_obtusifolia)
- [N,N-Dimethyltryptamine (DMT), an Endogenous Hallucinogen: Past, Present, and Future Research (PMC)](https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC6088236/)
- [Biosynthesis and Extracellular Concentrations of DMT in Mammalian Brain - Scientific Reports](https://www.nature.com/articles/s41598-019-45812-w)
- [Traditional Uses of Australian Acacias - WorldWideWattle](https://worldwidewattle.com/infogallery/utilisation/aboriginal.php)

════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════
SECTION: DRUG: Alcohol
Source: drugs-detailed/alcohol.md
════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════

# Alcohol

## Effects & Properties

**Effects:** Alcohol is a central nervous system depressant. In small
amounts, it produces relaxation, lowered inhibitions and mild euphoria. In higher doses, it
impairs motor skills, judgment, and can cause intoxication, nausea, or unconsciousness.

**Natural Occurrence:** Alcohol occurs naturally through
fermentation, where microorganisms like yeast convert sugars into ethanol and CO2. It’s found
in trace amounts in overripe fruits, fermented plant saps, or natural beverages like kombucha.
**Appearance:** Clear, colorless liquid at room
temperature with a slightly sweet, alcoholic odor and a burning taste.

## History

Archaeological evidence suggests that fermented beverages were produced as early as 7000 BCE in Jiahu, China, making alcohol one of the oldest psychoactive substances known to humanity. Alcohol has been central to virtually every major civilization, from Sumerian beer to Egyptian wine to European distilled spirits developed by Arab alchemists around the 8th century CE. Prohibition in the United States (1920-1933) demonstrated the impossibility of suppressing its use, and alcohol remains the most widely consumed legal intoxicant globally.

## Connections

**Archetype:** [Chicago Detroit](../core-lore/archetypes.md#chicago-detroit)

**Ancestor:** [Sicanje](../core-lore/ancestors/sicanje.md)

**Tarot Card:** [King of Pentacles](../core-lore/tarot-cards/king-of-pentacles.md)

**Paired With:** [Ethanol](ethanol.md)

## Sources

- https://www.erowid.org/chemicals/alcohol/alcohol.shtml
- https://pubchem.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/compound/Ethanol
- https://www.britannica.com/science/ethanol
- [Ethanol - Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ethanol)
- [Alcohol (drug) - Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alcohol_(drug))
- [History of alcoholic drinks - Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/History_of_alcoholic_drinks)
- [Prohibition in the United States - Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Prohibition_in_the_United_States)

════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════
SECTION: DRUG: Ancestral Trance
Source: drugs-detailed/ancestral-trance.md
════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════

# Ancestral Trance

## Effects & Properties

**Effects:** Altered perceptions, vivid hallucinations, and heightened
emotional states. Often accompanied by changes in thought patterns and a distorted sense of
time.

**Natural Occurrence:** LSD doesn’t occur in nature, it is best
known and most researched psychedelic. It is the standard against which all other psychedelics
are compared. It is active at extremely low doses and is most commonly available on blotter or
in liquid form.

## History

The practice of achieving altered states of consciousness through rhythmic drumming, chanting, hyperventilation, prolonged dance, and sensory deprivation predates all known drug use and may be as old as human consciousness itself, with evidence in Paleolithic cave art dating back 30,000-40,000 years. Trance states achieved without chemical substances are central to diverse spiritual traditions worldwide, from Aboriginal Australian corroborees to Haitian Vodou possession ceremonies to Orthodox Jewish ecstatic prayer (hitbodedut) to Sufi whirling dervish practices. This lineage connects directly to the modern rave experience, where sustained rhythmic movement, bass frequencies, and communal energy can induce non-chemical altered states, making ancestral trance the oldest and most universal human technology for transcendence.

## Connections

**Archetype:** [Freetekno](../core-lore/archetypes.md#freetekno)

**Ancestor:** [Orthodox Jews](../core-lore/ancestors/orthodox-jew.md), [Aboriginal](../core-lore/ancestors/aboriginal.md), [Haitians](../core-lore/ancestors/haitian.md)

**Tarot Card:** [Nine of Swords](../core-lore/tarot-cards/nine-of-swords.md)

**Paired With:** [LSD](lsd.md)

## Sources

- https://www.dea.gov/factsheets/lsd
- https://www.erowid.org/chemicals/lsd/lsd.shtml
- [Cave painting - Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cave_painting)
- [Corroboree - Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Corroboree)
- [Haitian Vodou - Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Haitian_Vodou)
- [Hitbodedut - Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hitbodedut)
- [Sufi whirling - Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sufi_whirling)

════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════
SECTION: DRUG: Arundo Donax
Source: drugs-detailed/arundo-donax.md
════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════

# Arundo Donax

## Effects & Properties

**Effects:** Diuretic, sudorific, and inti-inflammatory. Induces mild visual
distortions and altered perception.

**Natural Occurrence:** Native to the Mediterranean but invasive
globally, including California, this grass grows in riparian areas, reaching 9-30 feet tall. Arundo
donax’s traditional medicinal uses include treatment of skin, gastrointestinal, and urinary issues.
**Appearance:** Tall grass with hollow,
bamboo-like stems, pale green to blue-green leaves (up to 2 feet long), and plume-like cream to
brown flowerheads. Dried plant material is light brown to grayish-green with a grassy odor.

## History

Arundo donax (giant reed) has been used since antiquity in the Mediterranean region, with ancient Egyptians and Greeks employing it for making reeds for musical instruments, pens, and building materials. Its psychoactive potential was largely overlooked until the late 20th century, when researchers identified DMT and related tryptamine alkaloids in the plant's rhizomes and flowers. While not traditionally consumed as an entheogen, Arundo donax's DMT content has made it of interest to the modern psychedelic community, particularly as it grows abundantly as an invasive species in California and other warm climates.

## Connections

**Archetype:** [Acidhouse](../core-lore/archetypes.md#acidhouse)

**Ancestor:** [Native American](../core-lore/ancestors/native-american.md)

**Tarot Card:** [King of Swords](../core-lore/tarot-cards/king-of-swords.md)

**Paired With:** [DMT](dmt.md)

## Sources

- https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Arundo_donax
- https://www.erowid.org/plants/arundo_donax/arundo_donax.shtml
- [Arundo donax - DMT-Nexus Wiki](https://wiki.dmt-nexus.me/Arundo_donax)
- [The Invasive Mechanism and Impact of Arundo donax (PMC)](https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC12299341/)

════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════
SECTION: DRUG: Ashwagandha
Source: drugs-detailed/ashwagandha.md
════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════

# Ashwagandha

## Effects & Properties

**Effects:** Mild calming effects, reducing anxiety and stress without
sedation. Enhances mood, focus, and cognitive function with chronic use. Effects are subtle,
requiring 2-8 weeks for noticeable benefits.

**Natural Occurrence:** Native to India, the Middle East, and parts
of Africa, this small shrub grows in arid and semi-arid regions. Used in Ayurvedic medicine for
stress, anxiety, fatigue, and cognitive support. Available as capsules, powders, or teas in herbal
supplements.
**Appearance:** The plant has dull green, oval
leaves, small greenish-yellow flowers, and red-orange berries encased in papery calyx. Dried
roots are light brown to tan, often ground into a beige to brownish powder.

## History

Ashwagandha (Withania somnifera) has been one of the most important herbs in Ayurvedic medicine for over 3,000 years, described in the foundational Ayurvedic text Charaka Samhita as a rasayana (rejuvenator) that promotes longevity, vitality, and mental clarity. Its Sanskrit name means "smell of the horse," referring both to its distinctive odor and the traditional belief that it confers the strength and vigor of a stallion. Ashwagandha experienced a massive surge in Western popularity in the 2010s-2020s as an adaptogen supplement, driven by clinical studies demonstrating its efficacy in reducing cortisol and anxiety, making it one of the most commercially successful crossovers from traditional medicine to modern wellness culture.

## Connections

**Archetype:** [Milady](../core-lore/archetypes.md#milady)

**Ancestor:** [Hindu](../core-lore/ancestors/hindu.md)

**Tarot Card:** [The Hermit](../core-lore/tarot-cards/the-hermit.md)

**Paired With:** [Testosterone](testosterone.md)

## Sources

- https://www.drugs.com/npp/ashwagandha.html
- https://www.webmd.com/vitamins/ai/ingredientmono-953/ashwagandha
- https://pubchem.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/compound/Withanolide-A
- [Withania somnifera - Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Withania_somnifera)
- [An investigation into the stress-relieving and pharmacological actions of an ashwagandha extract (PMC)](https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC6750292/)
- [Ashwagandha: Is it helpful for stress, anxiety, or sleep? - NIH Office of Dietary Supplements](https://ods.od.nih.gov/factsheets/Ashwagandha-HealthProfessional/)

════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════
SECTION: DRUG: Ayahuasca
Source: drugs-detailed/ayahuasca.md
════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════

# Ayahuasca

## Effects & Properties

**Effects:** Vivid visual and auditory hallucinations, altered perception of time
and reality, increased heart rate, pupil dilation, and possible vomiting.

**Natural Occurrence:** Traditionally used in Amazonian shamanic
rituals for healing, divination, and spiritual growth. Recreationally consumed for psychedelic
experiences. Ayahuasca ceremonies are facilitated by trained shamans in South America and
increasingly globally.
**Appearance:** Based on Psychotria viridis,
it’s a shrub with glossy, dark green leaves, and small white flowers. Whilst Banisteriopsis caapi
is a woody vine with brown bark and green leaves. Ayahuasca brew is a brown to reddish-brown
liquid, often thick, with a bitter earthy taste and odor.

## History

Ayahuasca has been used by Indigenous Amazonian peoples for at least 1,000 years and possibly much longer, with the earliest archaeological evidence of ayahuasca preparation found in a Bolivian cave bundle dating to approximately 1000 CE. The brew, combining DMT-containing Psychotria viridis leaves with MAO-inhibiting Banisteriopsis caapi vine, was first documented by Western explorers including Richard Spruce in 1851 and later studied extensively by Richard Evans Schultes in the 1940s. The global ayahuasca movement exploded from the 1990s onward through Brazilian syncretic churches (Santo Daime and Uniao do Vegetal) and a growing network of retreat centers, making ayahuasca one of the most culturally significant psychedelic phenomena of the 21st century.

## Connections

**Archetype:** [Freetekno](../core-lore/archetypes.md#freetekno)

**Ancestor:** [Mayan](../core-lore/ancestors/mayan.md)

**Tarot Card:** [The Fool](../core-lore/tarot-cards/the-fool.md)

**Paired With:** [DMT](dmt.md)

## Sources

- https://www.erowid.org/chemicals/ayahuasca/ayahuasca.shtml
- https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ayahuasca
- https://pubchem.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/compound/Dimethyltryptamine
- [Banisteriopsis caapi - Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Banisteriopsis_caapi)
- [Richard Spruce - Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Richard_Spruce)

<!-- @generated:backlinks-start -->

════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════
SECTION: DRUG: Benadryl
Source: drugs-detailed/benadryl.md
════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════

# Benadryl

## Effects & Properties

**Effects:** Mild sedation, drowsiness, and reduced alertness, making it
effective for insomnia.

**Natural Occurrence:** Benadryl does not occur naturally, it was
first synthesized in 1943 by George Rievschl and is produced in laboratories. Widely available
as an over-the-counter medication as for now, for allergies, insomnia, and motion sickness.

## History

Diphenhydramine (marketed as Benadryl) was synthesized in 1943 by George Rieveschl, a professor at the University of Cincinnati, and it became the first prescription antihistamine approved by the FDA in 1946. Parke-Davis marketed it as Benadryl, and it transitioned to over-the-counter status in the 1980s, becoming one of the most widely used allergy and sleep medications. In the 2020s, Benadryl gained negative attention due to the dangerous "Benadryl Challenge" on social media, which involved taking high doses to induce deliriant hallucinations, highlighting the substance's toxic potential at supratherapeutic doses.

## Connections

**Archetype:** [Milady](../core-lore/archetypes.md#milady)

**Ancestor:** [Native American](../core-lore/ancestors/native-american.md)

**Tarot Card:** [Judgment](../core-lore/tarot-cards/judgment.md)

**Paired With:** [Datura](datura.md)

## Sources

- https://pubchem.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/compound/Diphenhydramine
- https://www.drugs.com/diphenhydramine.html
- https://www.webmd.com/drugs/2/drug-1428/diphenhydramine-oral/details
- [Diphenhydramine - Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Diphenhydramine)
- [George Rieveschl - Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/George_Rieveschl)

════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════
SECTION: DRUG: Bhang
Source: drugs-detailed/bhang.md
════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════

# Bhang

## Effects & Properties

**Effects:** Anti-inflammatory, relaxation, reduce anxiety.

**Natural Occurrence:** Native to South Asia, Bhang grows in
temperate and tropical regions. Bhang is used in cultural and religious contexts as a drink,
paste, or edible for relaxation and spiritual purposes.
**Appearance:** Green serrated leaves, dense,
resinous buds, and small seeds.

## History

Bhang is one of the oldest cannabis preparations in the world, with documented use in India dating back to at least 1000 BCE in the Atharva Veda, one of the four sacred Hindu texts, where cannabis was listed among the five sacred plants. It holds a unique legal and cultural status in India as a preparation associated with Lord Shiva, consumed widely during the festivals of Holi and Maha Shivaratri in the form of bhang lassi (a yogurt drink) or bhang thandai (a spiced milk drink). Government-licensed bhang shops operate legally throughout India, particularly in the states of Rajasthan, Uttar Pradesh, and Madhya Pradesh, making bhang one of the few cannabis products with continuous, unbroken legal use spanning millennia.

## Connections

**Archetype:** [Chicago Detroit](../core-lore/archetypes.md#chicago-detroit)

**Ancestor:** [Hindu](../core-lore/ancestors/hindu.md)

**Tarot Card:** [Ace of Cups](../core-lore/tarot-cards/ace-of-cups.md)

**Paired With:** [THC Edibles](thc-edibles.md)

## Sources

- https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bhang
- https://pubchem.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/compound/Cannabidiol
- https://www.drugs.com/cannabidiol.html
- [Cannabis in India - Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cannabis_in_India)
- [THC (Delta-9-tetrahydrocannabinol) - PubChem](https://pubchem.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/compound/Delta9-THC)

SECTION: DRUG: Brahmi
Source: drugs-detailed/brahmi.md
════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════

# Brahmi

## Effects & Properties

**Effects:** Enhances cognitive function, memory, and focus with chronic use.
Also produces mild calming effects, reducing anxiety, and stress without sedation. Effects are
subtle, requiring 4-12 weeks for noticeable benefits.

**Natural Occurrence:** Native to wetlands of India, Southeast Asia,
and Australia, this creeping herb grows in marshes and muddy shores.
**Appearance:** Plants which have small,
succulent green leaves, white to pale purple flowers, and a creeping structure. Dried Brahmi
appears as greenish-brown to brown with a mild earthy odor.

## History

Brahmi (Bacopa monnieri) has been used in Ayurvedic medicine for over 3,000 years, with references in ancient Vedic texts including the Charaka Samhita and Sushruta Samhita, where it was prescribed as a medhya rasayana (intellect rejuvenator) to enhance memory, learning, and concentration. Named after Brahma, the Hindu god of creation, it was traditionally given to scholars and students to aid memorization of lengthy sacred texts. Modern clinical research beginning in the 1960s at institutions in India and Australia has validated many of these traditional claims, demonstrating significant improvements in memory acquisition and retention.

## Connections

**Archetype:** [Chicago Detroit](../core-lore/archetypes.md#chicago-detroit)

**Ancestor:** [Hindu](../core-lore/ancestors/hindu.md)

**Tarot Card:** [Eight of Pentacles](../core-lore/tarot-cards/eight-of-pentacles.md)

**Paired With:** [Piracetam](piracetam.md)

## Sources

- https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bacopa_monnieri
- https://pubchem.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/compound/Bacoside-A
- [Neuropharmacological Review of the Nootropic Herb Bacopa monnieri (PMC)](https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC3746283/)
- [Bacopa monnieri - StatPearls (NCBI Bookshelf)](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK589635/)
- [Meta-analysis of randomized controlled trials on cognitive effects of Bacopa monnieri extract (PubMed)](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/24252493/)

SECTION: DRUG: Bufotenin
Source: drugs-detailed/bufotenin.md
════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════

# Bufotenin

## Effects & Properties

## History

Bufotenin was first isolated from toad skin (Bufo genus) in 1893 by the Austrian chemist Handovsky, and its presence in the seeds of Anadenanthera peregrina was later confirmed. Indigenous peoples of the Caribbean and South America have used bufotenine-containing snuffs such as cohoba and yopo for thousands of years in shamanic rituals for divination and spirit communication. The substance was studied in the mid-20th century by researchers including Fabing and Hawkins (1956), who controversially administered it to prison inmates, sparking debates about its psychoactive classification that continue today.

## Connections

**Archetype:** [Acidhouse](../core-lore/archetypes.md#acidhouse)

**Ancestor:** Native Americans


**Paired With:** [Bufotenin](bufotenin.md)

## Sources

- https://www.erowid.org/chemicals/bufotenin/bufotenin.shtml
- https://pubchem.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/compound/Bufotenin
- https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bufotenin
- [Anadenanthera peregrina - Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Anadenanthera_peregrina)
- [Cohoba - Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cohoba)
- [Bufotenin - Britannica](https://www.britannica.com/science/bufotenine)

════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════
SECTION: DRUG: Caffeine
Source: drugs-detailed/caffeine.md
════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════

# Caffeine

## Effects & Properties

**Effects:** Enhanced alertness, improved focus, mild euphoria, and reduced
sleepiness. It can improve cognitive performance and reaction time in low to moderate doses
(50-200mg). Physically it can increase heart rate, elevate blood pressure, mild diuresis, and in
some cases jitteriness or tremors.

**Natural Occurrence:** Caffeine is synthesized by plants as a
secondary metabolite to protect against insects and pathogens. It is present in seeds, leaves,
and fruits, with concentrations varying by species and environmental factors.

- Coffee beans contain 1-2% caffeine by weight.

- Tea leaves contain 2-5% caffeine varying by type.

- Cocoa beans contain small amounts of caffeine alongside theobromine.

- Found also in other plants such as kola nuts, guarana, and yerba mate.
**Appearance:** In coffee beans, it is part of a
dark brown, roasted seed matrix; in tea it is in dried green or black leaves, in guarana it is in
reddish seeds. These forms are not pure caffeine but contain it as a component.

## History

Caffeine consumption likely began in Ethiopia, where legend attributes the discovery of coffee to a goat herder named Kaldi around the 9th century CE who noticed his goats became energized after eating coffee berries. Tea consumption in China dates back even further, traditionally to Emperor Shen Nung around 2737 BCE. Coffeehouses became vital centers of intellectual and political discourse in the Ottoman Empire, Europe, and colonial America, and caffeine is now the most widely consumed psychoactive substance on Earth, with over two billion cups of coffee consumed daily worldwide.

## Connections

**Archetype:** [Milady](../core-lore/archetypes.md#milady)

**Ancestor:** [Ethiopian](../core-lore/ancestors/ethiopian.md), [Arabs](../core-lore/ancestors/arabs.md), Traveller, [Chinese](../core-lore/ancestors/chinese.md), [Japanese](../core-lore/ancestors/japanese.md)

**Tarot Card:** [The Sun](../core-lore/tarot-cards/the-sun.md)

**Paired With:** [Tea](tea.md), [Coffee](coffee.md)

## Sources

- https://www.erowid.org/chemicals/caffeine/caffeine.shtml
- https://www.britannica.com/science/caffeine
- https://pubchem.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/compound/Caffeine
- [Caffeine - Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Caffeine) — molecular formula C8H10N4O2, methylxanthine alkaloid classification, most widely consumed psychoactive substance, plant defense metabolite role, caffeine content in coffee beans and tea leaves
- [Kaldi - Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kaldi) — legend of the Ethiopian goat herder and coffee discovery (~9th century CE)
- [History of tea in China - Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/History_of_tea_in_China) — Emperor Shen Nung legend (2737 BCE)
- [History of coffee - Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/History_of_coffee) — coffeehouses in the Ottoman Empire and Europe, global spread of coffee culture

════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════
SECTION: DRUG: Cbd
Source: drugs-detailed/cbd.md
════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════

# CBD

## Effects & Properties

**Effects:** Intoxicant, stimulant, psychedelic, depressant.

**Natural Occurrence:** Cannabis produces psychoactive
cannabinoid chemicals such as THC and CBD. It is the most widely used (still mostly) illegal
psychoactive and has a long history of medicinal, recreational, and industrial use. The fibrous
stalks of the plant are used to produce clothing and rope. Its legal status is rapidly changing in
the US and around the world from top contraband to tolerated mind-alterant alongside alcohol
and caffeine.
- Cannabis sativa is a tall plant, generally between 8-12 feet. The leaves have long thin
fingers and are light green. The more equatorial varieties have more yellow pigments to
protect the plant from intense light. Sativa buds are long and thin and turn red as they
mature in a warm environment. In cooler environments the buds may be slightly purple.

- Cannabis indica, is a short plant, generally between 3-6 feet and its leaves have short
broad fingers. The leaves are generally dark green, sometimes tinged with purple. As
they near maturity the leaves may become significantly more purple.

- Cannabis ruderalis features large seeds, short weedy plants between 4-6 feet tall and a
lower level of THC than sativas or indicas.

## History

Cannabidiol (CBD) was first isolated from cannabis by American chemist Roger Adams in 1940, but its chemical structure was not fully elucidated until 1963 by Raphael Mechoulam and Yechiel Shvo in Israel. For decades CBD was overshadowed by THC research, but it gained dramatic public attention in 2013 when CNN aired the story of Charlotte Figi, a child with severe epilepsy whose seizures were dramatically reduced by a CBD-rich cannabis extract (later named "Charlotte's Web"). The 2018 US Farm Bill legalized hemp-derived CBD, triggering a massive consumer market and CBD's integration into wellness, beauty, and even rave recovery culture.

## Connections

**Archetype:** [Acidhouse](../core-lore/archetypes.md#acidhouse)

**Ancestor:** [Chinese](../core-lore/ancestors/chinese.md), [Native American](../core-lore/ancestors/native-american.md)

**Tarot Card:** [Seven of Pentacles](../core-lore/tarot-cards/seven-of-pentacles.md)

**Paired With:** [Kava](kava.md)

## Sources

- https://www.erowid.org/plants/cannabis/cannabis.shtml
- https://www.erowid.org/plants/cannabis/cannabis_info6.shtml
- [Cannabidiol - Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cannabidiol)
- [Raphael Mechoulam - Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Raphael_Mechoulam)
- [Cannabidiol - PubChem](https://pubchem.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/compound/Cannabidiol)

════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════
SECTION: DRUG: Chewing Tobacco
Source: drugs-detailed/chewing-tobacco.md
════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════

# Chewing Tobacco

## Effects & Properties

**Effects:** Stimulation / relaxation, short-term use may enhance memory and
attention. Addiction upon long-term usage.

**Natural Occurrence:** Native to the Americas, tobacco has a long
history of use as a shamanic inebriant and stimulant. Nicotine is a naturally occurring stimulant
found in tobacco (Nicotiana spp.) and other solanaceous plants. At room temperature, it is only
oily liquid. As a constituent of tobacco, it has been used for many centuries in the Americas and
Australia, and is now sold in a variety of common products worldwide.
**Appearance:** Annual or bi-annual growing
1-3 meters tall with large sticky leaves.

## History

Chewing tobacco has been used by Indigenous peoples of the Americas for thousands of years, with evidence of tobacco chewing among ancient Maya and North American tribes who combined it with lime or ash to enhance nicotine absorption. European colonists adopted the practice in the 16th and 17th centuries, and chewing tobacco became especially popular in rural America. In India, traditions of chewing tobacco mixed with betel leaf (paan) and areca nut date back centuries and remain deeply embedded in cultural practice, despite growing awareness of oral cancer risks.

## Connections

**Archetype:** [Chicago Detroit](../core-lore/archetypes.md#chicago-detroit)

**Ancestor:** Native americans, [Hindu](../core-lore/ancestors/hindu.md)

**Tarot Card:** [Two of Wands](../core-lore/tarot-cards/two-of-wands.md)

**Paired With:** [Pituri](pituri.md)

## Sources

- https://www.erowid.org/plants/tobacco/tobacco.shtml
- https://www.erowid.org/chemicals/nicotine/nicotine.shtml
- [Nicotine - Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nicotine)
- [Nicotine - PubChem](https://pubchem.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/compound/Nicotine)
- [History of tobacco - Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/History_of_tobacco)
- [Tobacco - Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tobacco)
- [Paan - Britannica](https://www.britannica.com/topic/paan)
- [Smokeless tobacco (paan and gutkha) consumption, prevalence, and contribution to oral cancer (PMC)](https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC5543298/)

## Miberas with this Drug

════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════
SECTION: DRUG: Clear Pill
Source: drugs-detailed/clear-pill.md
════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════

# Clear Pill

## Effects & Properties

**Effects:** In the brain, dopamine mediates reward, pleasure, and
motivation, contributing to feelings of satisfaction. It enhances focus, attention, and
goal-directed behavior, particularly in the mesolimbic pathway. Physically, dopamine regulates
blood pressure, heart rate, and kidney function by acting as a vasodilator or vasoconstrictor.
Excessive dopamine can cause agitation, paranoia, or psychosis.

**Natural Occurrence:** In animals, dopamine regulates
neurological and physiological processes, In plants, its role is less clear but may involve
defense or signaling. It is an endogenous compound, not requiring external administration for
natural effects.

**- Animal:** Synthesized in the brain, adrenal glands, and peripheral tissues from the amino
acid L-tyrosine via tyrosine hydroxlase. It is found in high concentration in the substantia
nigra, ventral tegmental area, and basal ganglia, playing a role in movement, reward,
and cognition. It is also present in blood and kidneys.

**- Plants:** Found in certain plants, notably bananas (Musa species) and Mucuna pruriens
(velvet beans), where it may function in stress responses or as a precursor to other
compounds. Concentrations in plants are low and not psychoactive when consumed due
to metabolism and blood-brain barrier.
**Appearance:** In nature, dopamine is not
visible as it exists in trace amounts within tissues or fluids. In its pure form, dopamine is a white
to off-white crystalline powder.

## History

Dopamine was first synthesized in 1910 by George Barger and James Ewens at the Wellcome Laboratories in London, but it was long considered merely a precursor to norepinephrine with no independent function. In 1958, Swedish pharmacologist Arvid Carlsson demonstrated that dopamine was a neurotransmitter in its own right, work for which he received the Nobel Prize in 2000. The understanding of dopamine's central role in motivation, reward, and pleasure has profoundly shaped modern neuroscience and popular culture, making "dopamine" synonymous with the neurochemistry of drive, ambition, and the pursuit of satisfaction.

## Connections

**Archetype:** [Milady](../core-lore/archetypes.md#milady)

**Ancestor:** [Satanist](../core-lore/ancestors/satanist.md)

**Tarot Card:** [Three of Pentacles](../core-lore/tarot-cards/three-of-pentacles.md)

**Paired With:** [Sober](sober.md)

## Sources

- https://pubchem.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/compound/Dopamine
- https://www.drugs.com/monograph/dopamine.html
- https://www.britannica.com/science/dopamine
- https://www.healthline.com/health/dopamine-effects
- [Dopamine - Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dopamine)
- [Arvid Carlsson - Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Arvid_Carlsson)
- [Mucuna pruriens - Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mucuna_pruriens)

════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════
SECTION: DRUG: Coca
Source: drugs-detailed/coca.md
════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════

# Coca

## Effects & Properties

**Effects:** Stimulant. Physically can increase heart rate, reduce appetite,
dilated pupils, and elevated blood pressure. High doses may cause tremors, agitation, or
seizures. It is highly addictive and can also cause anxiety, paranoia, and hallucinations.

**Natural Occurrence:** Native to South America, the plant is a
shrub cultivated in tropical and subtropical regions. Naturally, it serves as a chemical defense
against herbivores and pathogens, deterring consumption due to its bitter taste and toxicity.
Culturally, Indigenous Andean people have chewed coca leaves or brewed them as tea for
centuries to combat fatigue, hunger, and altitude sickness.
**Appearance:** The plants have glossy green
leaves, small white flowers, and red berries. Dried coca leaves are dark green to brownish with
a mild, earthy odor when used for chewing or tea.

## History

Coca leaves have been chewed by Andean peoples for at least 8,000 years, with archaeological evidence of coca use found in Peruvian burial sites dating to 6000 BCE, where it served as a sacred plant, appetite suppressant, and altitude sickness remedy. The Inca Empire formalized coca's spiritual significance, reserving it initially for nobility and priests. Spanish colonizers initially condemned coca use but later encouraged it among Indigenous mine laborers to suppress hunger and increase productivity, setting the stage for cocaine extraction by Albert Niemann in 1860 and the drug's complex modern history.

## Connections

**Archetype:** [Chicago Detroit](../core-lore/archetypes.md#chicago-detroit)

**Ancestor:** [Ballroom](../core-lore/ancestors/ballroom.md)

**Tarot Card:** [The World](../core-lore/tarot-cards/the-world.md)

**Paired With:** [Cocaine](cocaine.md)

## Sources

- https://www.erowid.org/plants/coca/coca.shtml
- https://pubchem.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/compound/Cocaine
- [Coca - Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Coca)
- [Erythroxylum coca - Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Erythroxylum_coca)
- [History of cocaine - Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/History_of_cocaine)
- [Albert Niemann (chemist) - Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Albert_Niemann_(chemist))
- [Coca: The History and Medical Significance of an Ancient Andean Tradition - PMC](https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC4838786/)

════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════
SECTION: DRUG: Cocaine
Source: drugs-detailed/cocaine.md
════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════

# Cocaine

## Effects & Properties

**Effects:** Stimulant. Physically can increase heart rate, reduce appetite,
dilated pupils, and elevated blood pressure. High doses may cause tremors, agitation, or
seizures. It is highly addictive and can also cause anxiety, paranoia, and hallucinations.

**Natural Occurrence:** Native to South America, the plant is a
shrub cultivated in tropical and subtropical regions. Naturally, it serves as a chemical defense
against herbivores and pathogens, deterring consumption due to its bitter taste and toxicity.
Culturally, Indigenous Andean people have chewed coca leaves or brewed them as tea for
centuries to combat fatigue, hunger, and altitude sickness.
**Appearance:** The plants have glossy green
leaves, small white flowers, and red berries. Dried coca leaves are dark green to brownish with
a mild, earthy odor when used for chewing or tea.

## History

Cocaine was first isolated from coca leaves by German chemist Albert Niemann in 1860, and its anesthetic and stimulant properties were widely promoted by figures including Sigmund Freud, who published "Uber Coca" in 1884. It was originally included in Coca-Cola (1886) and widely available in patent medicines before the Harrison Narcotics Act of 1914 restricted its sale in the United States. Cocaine fueled the disco and Studio 54 era of the 1970s-80s, and the crack epidemic devastated American inner cities in the late 1980s, while powdered cocaine remained associated with Wall Street excess and nightclub culture.

## Connections

**Archetype:** [Chicago Detroit](../core-lore/archetypes.md#chicago-detroit)

**Ancestor:** [Ballroom](../core-lore/ancestors/ballroom.md)

**Tarot Card:** [Three of Wands](../core-lore/tarot-cards/three-of-wands.md)

**Paired With:** [Coca](coca.md)

## Sources

- https://www.erowid.org/plants/coca/coca.shtml
- https://pubchem.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/compound/Cocaine
- [Cocaine - Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cocaine)
- [Albert Niemann (chemist) - Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Albert_Niemann_(chemist))
- [Erythroxylum coca - Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Erythroxylum_coca)
- [Harrison Narcotics Tax Act - Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Harrison_Narcotics_Tax_Act)
- [Crack epidemic in the United States - Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Crack_epidemic_in_the_United_States)
- [Uber Coca: Sigmund Freud, Carl Koller, and Cocaine - JAMA](https://jamanetwork.com/journals/jama/fullarticle/896143)

════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════
SECTION: DRUG: Coffee
Source: drugs-detailed/coffee.md
════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════

# Coffee

## Effects & Properties

**Effects:** Enhanced alertness, improved focus, mild euphoria, and reduced
sleepiness. It can improve cognitive performance and reaction time in low to moderate doses
(50-200mg). Physically it can increase heart rate, elevate blood pressure, mild diuresis, and in
some cases jitteriness or tremors.

**Natural Occurrence:** Caffeine is synthesized by plants as a
secondary metabolite to protect against insects and pathogens. It is present in seeds, leaves,
and fruits, with concentrations varying by species and environmental factors.

- Coffee beans contain 1-2% caffeine by weight.

- Tea leaves contain 2-5% caffeine varying by type.

- Cocoa beans contain small amounts of caffeine alongside theobromine.

- Found also in other plants such as kola nuts, guarana, and yerba mate.
**Appearance:** In coffee beans, it is part of a
dark brown, roasted seed matrix; in tea it is in dried green or black leaves, in guarana it is in
reddish seeds. These forms are not pure caffeine but contain it as a component.

## History

Coffee's origins trace to Ethiopia, where, according to legend, a goat herder named Kaldi discovered the stimulating effects of coffee berries around the 9th century CE. Sufi monks in Yemen were among the first to cultivate and brew coffee for sustained prayer and meditation by the 15th century, and coffeehouses (qahveh khaneh) spread rapidly through the Ottoman Empire. European coffeehouses emerged in the 17th century as "penny universities" where intellectuals, merchants, and revolutionaries gathered, and coffee went on to become the world's second most traded commodity after oil, with over 2.25 billion cups consumed daily.

## Connections

**Archetype:** [Milady](../core-lore/archetypes.md#milady)

**Ancestor:** [Ethiopian](../core-lore/ancestors/ethiopian.md), [Arabs](../core-lore/ancestors/arabs.md), Traveller

**Tarot Card:** [Four of Pentacles](../core-lore/tarot-cards/four-of-pentacles.md)

**Paired With:** [Caffeine](caffeine.md)

## Sources

- https://www.erowid.org/chemicals/caffeine/caffeine.shtml
- https://www.britannica.com/science/caffeine
- https://pubchem.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/compound/Caffeine
- [History of coffee - Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/History_of_coffee)
- [Caffeine - Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Caffeine)

════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════
SECTION: DRUG: Datura
Source: drugs-detailed/datura.md
════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════

# Datura

## Effects & Properties

**Effects:** Vivid hallucinations, disorientation, visual distortions, and
amnesia. Datura is highly toxic, with risks including severe delirium, agitation, seizures, and
coma.

**Natural Occurrence:** Datura has been used in traditional
medicine and rituals for its sedative and hallucinogenic properties, particularly in Native
American and South Asian cultures. The weed grows worldwide in temperate and tropical
regions, often in disturbed soils.
**Appearance:** Woody-stalked, leafy herb
growing up to 2 meters. The plant has large, coarse, green leaves, trumpet-shaped white or
purple flowers, and spiky seed pods. Dried leaves or seeds appear as grayish-green to
brownish material, with a bitter, unpleasant odor.

## History

Datura species have been used in shamanic and ritual contexts for thousands of years across multiple continents, with archaeological evidence of Datura use in the American Southwest dating to at least 1000 BCE. It was sacred to both Aztec priests (as toloache) and Hindu devotees of Shiva in India, and it features prominently in European witchcraft traditions as an ingredient in "flying ointments." Datura's extreme unpredictability and toxicity have given it a fearsome reputation, and unlike most psychedelics, users rarely report positive experiences, leading to its characterization as a deliriant rather than a true hallucinogen.

## Connections

**Archetype:** [Milady](../core-lore/archetypes.md#milady)

**Ancestor:** [Native American](../core-lore/ancestors/native-american.md)

**Tarot Card:** [Knight of Wands](../core-lore/tarot-cards/knight-of-wands.md)

**Paired With:** [Psychotria Viridis](psychotria-viridis.md), [Benadryl](benadryl.md)

## Sources

- https://erowid.org/plants/datura/datura.shtml
- https://pubchem.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/compound/Hyoscyamine#section=Use-and-Manufacturing
- https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Datura
- [Flying ointment - Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Flying_ointment)
- [Datura stramonium - Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Datura_stramonium)
- [Deliriant - Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Deliriant)
- [Aztec use of entheogens - Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Aztec_use_of_entheogens)
- [Datura metel - Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Datura_metel)
- [Datura quids at Pinwheel Cave, California (PNAS)](https://www.pnas.org/doi/10.1073/pnas.2014529117)

<!-- @generated:backlinks-start -->
## Miberas with this Drug

SECTION: DRUG: Dextroamphetamine
Source: drugs-detailed/dextroamphetamine.md
════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════

# Dextroamphetamine

## Effects & Properties

**Effects:** Enhances focus, alertness, and energy, with mild euphoria at
therapeutic doses. Recreational doses can induce intense euphoria, increased confidence, and
talkativeness..

**Natural Occurrence:** Dextroamphetamine does not occur
naturally and is a synthetic compound.

## History

Amphetamine was first synthesized by Romanian chemist Lazar Edeleanu in Berlin in 1887, and its dextro-rotatory isomer (dextroamphetamine) was identified as the more potent stimulant enantiomer. Smith, Kline and French marketed dextroamphetamine as Dexedrine in 1937 for narcolepsy and depression, and it was widely distributed to Allied soldiers during World War II as a performance enhancer. Dextroamphetamine became a foundation of modern ADHD treatment through medications like Adderall (approved 1996), and its non-medical use is widespread in academic, professional, and party contexts.

## Connections

**Archetype:** [Milady](../core-lore/archetypes.md#milady)

**Ancestor:** [Chinese](../core-lore/ancestors/chinese.md), [Palestinian](../core-lore/ancestors/palestinian.md)

**Tarot Card:** [Five of Wands](../core-lore/tarot-cards/five-of-wands.md)

**Paired With:** [Ephedra](ephedra.md)

## Sources

- https://pubchem.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/compound/Dextroamphetamine
- https://www.drugs.com/mtm/dextroamphetamine.html
- [Dextroamphetamine - Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dextroamphetamine)
- [Amphetamine - Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Amphetamine)

<!-- @generated:backlinks-start -->
## Miberas with this Drug

[#0037](../miberas/0037.md) • [#0064](../miberas/0064.md) • [#0103](../miberas/0103.md) • [#0147](../miberas/0147.md) • [#0311](../miberas/0311.md) • [#0315](../miberas/0315.md) • [#0490](../miberas/0490.md) • [#0519](../miberas/0519.md) • [#0536](../miberas/0536.md) • [#0567](../miberas/0567.md) • [#0571](../miberas/0571.md) • [#0588](../miberas/0588.md) • [#0767](../miberas/0767.md) • [#0841](../miberas/0841.md) • [#0969](../miberas/0969.md) • [#1023](../miberas/1023.md) • [#1181](../miberas/1181.md) • [#1260](../miberas/1260.md) • [#1453](../miberas/1453.md) • [#1616](../miberas/1616.md) • [#1702](../miberas/1702.md) • [#1836](../miberas/1836.md) • [#1850](../miberas/1850.md) • [#1929](../miberas/1929.md) • [#2009](../miberas/2009.md) • [#2213](../miberas/2213.md) • [#2264](../miberas/2264.md) • [#2291](../miberas/2291.md) • [#2371](../miberas/2371.md) • [#2539](../miberas/2539.md) • [#2556](../miberas/2556.md) • [#2609](../miberas/2609.md) • [#2905](../miberas/2905.md) • [#3015](../miberas/3015.md) • [#3089](../miberas/3089.md) • [#3112](../miberas/3112.md) • [#3385](../miberas/3385.md) • [#3440](../miberas/3440.md) • [#3765](../miberas/3765.md) • [#3822](../miberas/3822.md) • [#3823](../miberas/3823.md) • [#3945](../miberas/3945.md) • [#4003](../miberas/4003.md) • [#4185](../miberas/4185.md) • [#4191](../miberas/4191.md) • [#4227](../miberas/4227.md) • [#4231](../miberas/4231.md) • [#4774](../miberas/4774.md) • [#4932](../miberas/4932.md) • [#5267](../miberas/5267.md) • ... and 42 more

════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════
SECTION: DRUG: Dmt
Source: drugs-detailed/dmt.md
════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════

# DMT

## Effects & Properties

**Effects:** Vivid visual and auditory hallucinations, altered sense of time and
reality, euphoria, and profound spiritual or mystical experiences. Physically it can increase heart
rate and blood pressure, pupil dilation, and in some cases nausea. In higher doses or
unprepared settings can cause anxiety, panic, or disorientation.

**Natural Occurrence:** In plants, DMT likely serves as a defense
against herbivores or pathogens. In humans its endogenous presence is under study with
theories linking it to dreaming, near-death experiences, or spiritual phenomena (speculative).

**- Plants:** Found in numerous plant species, particularly those used in traditional
psychoactive preparations, such as Psychotria viridis (chacruna), Banisteriopsis caapi,
Mimosa tenuiflora, and Acacia species. It is present in leaves, bark, or roots, often in low
concentrations.

**- Animals:** Trace amounts are detected in the brain, blood, and urine of mammals,
including humans.

**- Fungi and Toads:** Present in some fungi (Psilocybe species, etc) and certain toad
venoms.
**Appearance:** DMT is not visible in plants or
animals but is extracted as a powder or resin from plant material (Mimosa tenuiflora root bark
yields a reddish-brown extract, in Ayahuasca it is part of a dark, bitter liquid brew).

## History

DMT was first synthesized by Canadian chemist Richard Manske in 1931, though its psychoactive properties were not recognized until Hungarian chemist Stephen Szara self-administered it via injection in 1956 and reported intense visionary experiences. Indigenous Amazonian peoples had been using DMT-containing plant preparations such as ayahuasca and snuffs like yopo for thousands of years prior. Rick Strassman's clinical research at the University of New Mexico in the 1990s, published as "DMT: The Spirit Molecule," reignited scientific and popular interest, and DMT has since become a substance of fascination in psychedelic and electronic music subcultures.

## Connections

**Archetype:** [Acidhouse](../core-lore/archetypes.md#acidhouse)

**Ancestor:** [Mayan](../core-lore/ancestors/mayan.md), [Aboriginal](../core-lore/ancestors/aboriginal.md), [Native American](../core-lore/ancestors/native-american.md)

**Tarot Card:** [Ten of Swords](../core-lore/tarot-cards/ten-of-swords.md)

**Paired With:** [Ayahuasca](ayahuasca.md), [Mimosa Tenuiflora](mimosa-tenuiflora.md), [Acacia](acacia.md), [Arundo Donax](arundo-donax.md), [Mucuna Pruriens](mucuna-pruriens.md)

## Sources

- https://www.erowid.org/chemicals/dmt/dmt.shtml
- https://erowid.org/chemicals/dmt/dmt_info2.shtml
- https://pubchem.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/compound/N_N-Dimethyltryptamine
- [Dimethyltryptamine - Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dimethyltryptamine) — molecular formula C12H16N2, first synthesized by Richard Manske (1931), psychoactive effects reported by Stephen Szara (1956), endogenous presence in mammals
- [Ayahuasca - Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ayahuasca) — indigenous Amazonian use of DMT-containing plant preparations (Psychotria viridis, Banisteriopsis caapi)
- [Anadenanthera peregrina - Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Anadenanthera_peregrina) — yopo snuff use for thousands of years in South America
- [Rick Strassman - Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rick_Strassman) — DMT clinical research at University of New Mexico (1990-1995), author of DMT: The Spirit Molecule
- [N,N-Dimethyltryptamine (DMT), an Endogenous Hallucinogen - PMC](https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC6088236/) — comprehensive review of DMT history, synthesis, and pharmacology

<!-- @generated:backlinks-start -->
## Miberas with this Drug
