════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════
SECTION: DRUG: Kwao Krua
Source: drugs-detailed/kwao-krua.md
════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════

# Kwao Krua

## Effects & Properties

**Effects:** Menopausal symptom relief, maintaining bone density in
estrogen-deficient models, promoting collagen production, skin elasticity, and wrinkle reduction.
It may also have antioxidant effects and inhibit growth of breast cancer cell lines, though in high
doses may promote estrogen-sensitive tumors. Mild side effects include breast tenderness,
bloating, headaches, and irregular periods.

**Natural Occurrence:** The substances are unique to Puerarie
mirifica.
**Appearance:** The plant’s tuberous roots
resemble potatoes in their raw form, with a brownish exterior and whitish interior. Dried and
powdered, the roots appear as light brown to beige with an earthy odor.

## History

Kwao Krua (Pueraria mirifica) has been used in traditional Thai medicine for centuries, with the earliest known written reference appearing in a palm-leaf manuscript from Myanmar dating to 1227 CE, describing its rejuvenating and feminizing properties. The plant was formally identified by the Thai botanist Luang Anusarnsuntarakromkarnpithak in 1931 and documented scientifically by Kashemsanta in 1952. It gained international attention in the late 20th century for its potent phytoestrogens, particularly miroestrol, and is now widely marketed as a natural supplement for menopausal relief and breast enhancement.

## Connections

**Archetype:** [Milady](../core-lore/archetypes.md#milady)

**Ancestor:** [Thai](../core-lore/ancestors/thai.md)

**Tarot Card:** [Two of Pentacles](../core-lore/tarot-cards/two-of-pentacles.md)

**Paired With:** [Estrogen](estrogen.md)

## Sources

- https://biologyinsights.com/pueraria-mirifica-applications-side-effects-safety/
- https://www.healthline.com/nutrition/pueraria-mirifica
- [Pueraria mirifica - Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pueraria_mirifica) — botanical identification, 13th-century palm-leaf manuscript reference, phytoestrogens including miroestrol, traditional Thai medicinal use
- [Miroestrol - PubChem](https://pubchem.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/compound/Miroestrol) — miroestrol molecular data

SECTION: DRUG: Kykeon
Source: drugs-detailed/kykeon.md
════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════

# Kykeon

## Effects & Properties

**Effects:** Kykeon may produce mild psychoactive effects at high doses, and
could theoretically induce visionary experiences. Common side effects include nausea,
vomiting, dizziness, and muscle cramps due to vasoconstriction. High doses can cause
ergotism, a serious condition with symptoms like severe vasoconstriction, convulsions,
hallucinations, or psychosis.

**Natural Occurrence:** Found in ergot sclerotia on grasses like rye,
wheat, and barley, with concentrations varying. The fungus thrives in damp conditions,
historically contaminating grain supplies in Europe.
Kykeon contained ergot alkaloids stems from the use of barley in its recipe.
**Appearance:** In nature, it exists in
ergot-infected grains, showing as a dark purple to black sclerotia which replace healthy grain
kernels. These sclerotia are hard and irregular, contrasting with the lighter grain.
Kykeon itself is a liquid beverage, likely cloudy or brownish due to barley and mint, and would
resemble a grain-based porridge or drink, not a pure chemical.

## History

Kykeon was the sacred ritual drink consumed by initiates of the Eleusinian Mysteries in ancient Greece, ceremonies held annually for nearly 2,000 years (circa 1500 BCE to 392 CE) at the sanctuary of Eleusis near Athens. The exact recipe remains debated, but it is known to have contained barley, water, and mint; scholars including R. Gordon Wasson, Albert Hofmann, and Carl Ruck proposed in their 1978 book "The Road to Eleusis" that ergot-contaminated barley may have provided psychoactive alkaloids similar to LSD. The Mysteries were considered the most important spiritual event in the ancient Greek world, with initiates including Plato, Sophocles, and Cicero reporting profound, life-changing visionary experiences.

## Connections

**Archetype:** [Acidhouse](../core-lore/archetypes.md#acidhouse)

**Ancestor:** [Greek](../core-lore/ancestors/greek.md)

**Tarot Card:** [Ten of Cups](../core-lore/tarot-cards/ten-of-cups.md)

**Paired With:** [Shroom Tea](shroom-tea.md)

## Sources

- https://www.erowid.org/plants/ergot/ergot.shtml
- https://pubchem.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/compound/Ergotamine
- https://www.historicmysteries.com/kykeon/
- [Kykeon - Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kykeon)
- [Eleusinian Mysteries - Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Eleusinian_Mysteries)
- [Ergotism - Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ergotism)
- [Ergot - Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ergot)

SECTION: DRUG: Lamotrigine
Source: drugs-detailed/lamotrigine.md
════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════

# Lamotrigine

## Effects & Properties

**Effects:** Lamotrigine is an anticonvulsant and mood-stabilizing medication
primarily used to treat epilepsy (to control seizures) and bipolar disorder (to prevent mood
swings, particularly depressive episodes). Common side effects include dehydration, dizziness,
headache, nausea, and in some cases skin rashes.

**Natural Occurrence:** Lamotrigine does not occur naturally and is
purely a synthetic compound.

## History

Lamotrigine was developed by GlaxoSmithKline's precursor Wellcome Research Laboratories in the UK during the 1980s, initially as an anticonvulsant for epilepsy. It received FDA approval in the United States in 1994 for epilepsy treatment and was subsequently approved for bipolar disorder maintenance therapy in 2003. Its relatively mild side effect profile compared to older mood stabilizers like lithium has made it one of the most widely prescribed psychiatric medications worldwide.

## Connections

**Archetype:** [Acidhouse](../core-lore/archetypes.md#acidhouse)

**Ancestor:** [Irish Druids](../core-lore/ancestors/irish-druids.md)

**Tarot Card:** [Justice](../core-lore/tarot-cards/justice.md)

**Paired With:** [Lithium](lithium.md)

## Sources

- https://pubchem.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/compound/Lamotrigine
- https://www.drugs.com/monograph/lamotrigine.html
- https://medlineplus.gov/druginfo/meds/a695007.html
- [Lamotrigine - Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lamotrigine)
- [Lamotrigine - StatPearls (NCBI)](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK470442/)

════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════
SECTION: DRUG: Lithium
Source: drugs-detailed/lithium.md
════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════

# Lithium

## Effects & Properties

**Effects:** Stabilizes mood, reducing manic and depressive episodes in
bipolar disorder. May cause mild tremor, increased thirst, frequent urination, and weight gain.

**Natural Occurrence:** Lithium carbonate is a synthetic compound
and does not occur naturally in its pharmaceutical form. However, lithium (the metal) is found in
trace amounts in minerals and human tissues.

## History

Lithium was first discovered as an element by Swedish chemist Johan August Arfwedson in 1817 in the mineral petalite. Its psychiatric applications were pioneered by Australian psychiatrist John Cade, who in 1949 discovered lithium's remarkable ability to calm manic episodes after testing lithium salts on guinea pigs, marking one of the most important breakthroughs in the history of psychiatry. Despite Cade's discovery, lithium was not approved by the FDA for bipolar disorder treatment until 1970, partly due to pharmaceutical companies' lack of interest in patenting a naturally occurring element, and it remains the gold standard mood stabilizer to this day.

## Connections

**Archetype:** [Acidhouse](../core-lore/archetypes.md#acidhouse)

**Ancestor:** [Irish Druids](../core-lore/ancestors/irish-druids.md)

**Tarot Card:** [Queen of Pentacles](../core-lore/tarot-cards/queen-of-pentacles.md)

**Paired With:** [Lamotrigine](lamotrigine.md)

## Sources

- https://pubchem.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/compound/Lithium-carbonate
- https://www.drugs.com/lithium.html
- https://www.webmd.com/drugs/2/drug-5887-795/lithium-carbonate-oral/lithium-controlled-releas
- [Lithium (medication) - Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lithium_(medication))
- [Johan August Arfwedson - Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Johan_August_Arfwedson)
- [John Cade - Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/John_Cade)

════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════
SECTION: DRUG: Lsd
Source: drugs-detailed/lsd.md
════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════

# LSD

## Effects & Properties

**Effects:** Altered perceptions, vivid hallucinations, and heightened
emotional states. Often accompanied by changes in thought patterns and a distorted sense of
time.

**Natural Occurrence:** LSD doesn’t occur in nature, it is best
known and most researched psychedelic. It is the standard against which all other psychedelics
are compared. It is active at extremely low doses and is most commonly available on blotter or
in liquid form.

## History

Albert Hofmann first synthesized LSD at Sandoz Laboratories in Basel, Switzerland in 1938, and accidentally discovered its psychoactive effects in 1943 during the famous "Bicycle Day" (April 19). It became central to 1960s counterculture through Timothy Leary and Ken Kesey's Merry Pranksters, before being banned in the US in 1968. LSD resurfaced in the late 1980s acid house movement and remains foundational to psychedelic rave culture.

## Connections

**Archetype:** [Freetekno](../core-lore/archetypes.md#freetekno)

**Ancestor:** [Aboriginals](../core-lore/ancestors/aboriginal.md), [Haitians](../core-lore/ancestors/haitian.md)

**Tarot Card:** [The Star](../core-lore/tarot-cards/the-star.md)

**Paired With:** [Ancestral Trance](ancestral-trance.md), [Ololiuqui](ololiuqui.md)

## Sources

- https://www.dea.gov/factsheets/lsd
- https://www.erowid.org/chemicals/lsd/lsd.shtml
- [Lysergic acid diethylamide (LSD) - Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/LSD)
- [History of LSD - Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/History_of_LSD)
- [Albert Hofmann - Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Albert_Hofmann)
- [Bicycle Day - Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bicycle_Day_(psychedelic_holiday))
- [The Pharmacology of Lysergic Acid Diethylamide: A Review - PMC](https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC6494066/)

SECTION: DRUG: M Cat
Source: drugs-detailed/m-cat.md
════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════

# M-Cat

## Effects & Properties

**Effects:** M-Cat / Mephedrone acts as a central nervous system stimulant
by increasing levels of dopamine, serotonin, and norepinephrine in the brain through reuptake
inhibition and release. It invokes euphoria, increased energy and sociability, and heightened
alertness. However, it can also cause adverse effects such as anxiety, paranoia, rapid heart
rate, sweating, and in high doses can lead to seizures or cardiovascular issues.

**Natural Occurrence:** M-cat does not occur in nature.

## History

Mephedrone (4-methylmethcathinone) was first synthesized in 1929 by the French pharmacologist Saem de Burnaga Sanchez, but remained obscure until it was rediscovered and sold online as a "legal high" and "plant food" beginning around 2007. It exploded in popularity across the UK club and rave scene in 2009-2010, becoming briefly more popular than cocaine in some nightlife contexts. The UK banned mephedrone in April 2010 as a Class B drug, followed by similar bans across the EU, though it remains widely available on the black market.

## Connections

**Archetype:** [Freetekno](../core-lore/archetypes.md#freetekno)

**Ancestor:** Ethiopians

**Tarot Card:** [King of Wands](../core-lore/tarot-cards/king-of-wands.md)

**Paired With:** [Khat](khat.md)

## Sources

- https://www.erowid.org/chemicals/4_methylmethcathinone/4_methylmethcathinone.shtml
- https://pubchem.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/compound/Mephedrone
- [Mephedrone - Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mephedrone)
- [MDA, MDMA, and other mescaline-like substances in the US military search for a truth drug (PubMed)](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/28851034/)
- [Britain moves to curtail new drug craze (PMC)](https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC2882479/)

════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════
SECTION: DRUG: Mandrake
Source: drugs-detailed/mandrake.md
════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════

# Mandrake

## Effects & Properties

**Effects:** At high doses induces delirium, vivid hallucinations, confusion,
and disorientation. Medically can be used to treat motion sickness, postoperative nausea, and
irritable bowel syndrome.

**Natural Occurrence:** Native to the Mediterranean and Middle
East, this herb grows in dry sunny areas. Historically, mandrake was used in European and
Mediterranean folk medicine and rituals as a sedative, aphrodisiac, etc.
**Appearance:** The plant has a rosette of
dark green, wrinkled leaves, purple or yellowish flowers, and a thick forked root, resembling a
human figure (hence its mythical status). Dried roots or leaves are brown to grayish with an
earthy bitter odor.

## History

Mandrake (Mandragora officinarum) is one of the most mythologized plants in Western history, with references in the Hebrew Bible (Genesis 30:14), ancient Egyptian texts, and Greek writings by Theophrastus and Dioscorides dating to the 4th century BCE. Medieval European folklore held that the mandrake root screamed when pulled from the ground and that the sound could kill the harvester, leading to elaborate rituals involving dogs tied to the root. Mandrake was a key ingredient in medieval surgical anesthesia (the "soporific sponge") and in witches' "flying ointments," and its human-shaped root made it one of the most potent symbols in Western occult tradition.

## Connections

**Archetype:** [Freetekno](../core-lore/archetypes.md#freetekno)

**Ancestor:** [Greek](../core-lore/ancestors/greek.md), [Arabs](../core-lore/ancestors/arabs.md)

**Tarot Card:** [Four of Swords](../core-lore/tarot-cards/four-of-swords.md)

**Paired With:** [Xanax](xanax.md)

## Sources

- https://erowid.org/plants/mandrake/mandrake.shtml
- https://pubchem.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/compound/Scopolamine
- https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mandrake
- [Mandragora officinarum - Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mandragora_officinarum)
- [Hyoscyamine - PubChem](https://pubchem.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/compound/Hyoscyamine)

<!-- @generated:backlinks-start -->
## Miberas with this Drug

════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════
SECTION: DRUG: Mda
Source: drugs-detailed/mda.md
════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════

# MDA

## Effects & Properties

**Effects:** Euphoria, increased empathy, heightened sensory perception,
mild to moderate hallucinations, and increased energy. Physically, it can increase heart rate,
elevate blood pressure, pupil dilation, jaw clenching, sweating, and in some cases nausea.
Potential risks include anxiety, paranoia, dehydration, and hyperthermia.

**Natural Occurrence:** MDA does not occur naturally.

## History

MDA (3,4-methylenedioxyamphetamine) was first synthesized by German chemists G. Mannish and W. Jacobsohn in 1910, and its psychoactive effects were explored by the US military in the 1950s as part of Project MKUltra. It gained the street name "the love drug" in the 1960s counterculture and was used therapeutically by psychotherapist Claudio Naranjo before being classified as a Schedule I substance in 1970. MDA served as a precursor to the development of MDMA and influenced the entactogen class of drugs that would later become central to rave culture.

## Connections

**Archetype:** [Milady](../core-lore/archetypes.md#milady)

**Ancestor:** Native Americans

**Tarot Card:** [Four of Wands](../core-lore/tarot-cards/four-of-wands.md)

**Paired With:** [Sassafras](sassafras.md)

## Sources

- https://www.erowid.org/chemicals/mda/mda.shtml
- https://pubchem.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/compound/3_4-Methylenedioxyamphetamine
- [3,4-Methylenedioxyamphetamine - Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/3,4-Methylenedioxyamphetamine)
- [MKUltra - Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/MKUltra)
- [Claudio Naranjo - Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Claudio_Naranjo)
- [The History of MDMA as an Underground Drug in the United States, 1960-1979 (PubMed)](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/26940772/)

════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════
SECTION: DRUG: Mdma
Source: drugs-detailed/mdma.md
════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════

# MDMA

## Effects & Properties

**Effects:** Euphoria, emotional warmth, empathy, increased sociability,
heightened sensory perception, and enhanced emotional connection.

**Natural Occurrence:** MDMA does not occur naturally.

## History

MDMA (3,4-methylenedioxymethamphetamine) was first synthesized by Merck chemist Anton Kollisch in 1912 as an intermediate compound in a pharmaceutical patent, and its psychoactive effects went unrecognized for decades. Alexander Shulgin resynthesized it in 1976 and introduced it to psychotherapist Leo Zeff, who championed it as a therapeutic tool nicknamed "Adam" for its ability to return patients to a state of emotional openness. MDMA became synonymous with rave culture after fueling the Second Summer of Love in the UK in 1988-1989, and it remains the defining drug of electronic dance music culture worldwide, with ongoing clinical trials now advancing toward FDA-approved PTSD therapy.

## Connections

**Archetype:** [Milady](../core-lore/archetypes.md#milady)

**Ancestor:** [Native American](../core-lore/ancestors/native-american.md)

**Tarot Card:** [The Lovers](../core-lore/tarot-cards/the-lovers.md)

**Paired With:** [Sassafras](sassafras.md)

## Sources

- https://erowid.org/chemicals/mdma/mdma.shtml
- https://pubchem.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/compound/MDMA
- https://www.drugs.com/illicit/mdma.html
- [MDMA - Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/MDMA)
- [Anton Kollisch - Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Anton_Kollisch)
- [Alexander Shulgin - Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alexander_Shulgin)
- [Second Summer of Love - Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Second_Summer_of_Love)
- [MDMA-assisted psychotherapy - Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/MDMA-assisted_psychotherapy)
- [3,4-Methylenedioxymethamphetamine | C11H15NO2 - PubChem](https://pubchem.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/compound/3_4-Methylenedioxymethamphetamine)

════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════
SECTION: DRUG: Methamphetamine
Source: drugs-detailed/methamphetamine.md
════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════

# Methamphetamine

## Effects & Properties

**Effects:** Intense euphoria, heightened alertness, increased energy,
enhanced focus, and feelings of confidence or invincibility. Users may experience talkativeness,
sociability, and reduced need for sleep. Physically it can increase heart rate and blood pressure,
hyperthermia, pupil dilation, reduced appetite, and in some cases, tremors or jaw clenching.
Common side effects include anxiety, agitation, paranoia, and insomnia.

**Natural Occurrence:** Methamphetamine does not occur
naturally.

## History

Methamphetamine was first synthesized by Japanese chemist Nagai Nagayoshi in 1893 from ephedrine, and a more potent crystallized form was developed by Akira Ogata in 1919. It was widely distributed during World War II to soldiers on all sides under brand names like Pervitin (Germany) and Philopon (Japan) to combat fatigue and boost aggression. Post-war methamphetamine abuse became epidemic in Japan and later in the United States, where it fueled the biker and crank cultures of the 1960s-80s before the crystal meth epidemic devastated rural communities in the 1990s and 2000s.

## Connections

**Archetype:** [Milady](../core-lore/archetypes.md#milady)

**Ancestor:** [Chinese](../core-lore/ancestors/chinese.md), [Palestinian](../core-lore/ancestors/palestinian.md)

**Tarot Card:** [The Devil](../core-lore/tarot-cards/the-devil.md)

**Paired With:** [Ephedra](ephedra.md)

## Sources

- https://erowid.org/chemicals/meth/meth.shtml
- https://erowid.org/chemicals/meth/meth_testing.shtml
- https://www.drugs.com/monograph/methamphetamine.html
- https://pubchem.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/compound/Methamphetamine
- [Methamphetamine - Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Methamphetamine)
- [Nagai Nagayoshi - Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nagai_Nagayoshi)
- [History and culture of substituted amphetamines - Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/History_and_culture_of_substituted_amphetamines)
- [Drug policy of Nazi Germany - Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Drug_policy_of_Nazi_Germany)

════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════
SECTION: DRUG: Mimosa Tenuiflora
Source: drugs-detailed/mimosa-tenuiflora.md
════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════

# Mimosa Tenuiflora

## Effects & Properties

**Effects:** Vivid visual and auditory hallucinations, altered sense of time and
reality, euphoria, and profound spiritual or mystical experiences. Physically it can increase heart
rate and blood pressure, pupil dilation, and in some cases nausea. In higher doses or
unprepared settings can cause anxiety, panic, or disorientation.

**Natural Occurrence:** In plants, DMT likely serves as a defense
against herbivores or pathogens. In humans its endogenous presence is under study with
theories linking it to dreaming, near-death experiences, or spiritual phenomena (speculative).

**- Plants:** Found in numerous plant species, particularly those used in traditional
psychoactive preparations, such as Psychotria viridis (chacruna), Banisteriopsis caapi,
Mimosa tenuiflora, and Acacia species. It is present in leaves, bark, or roots, often in low
concentrations.

**- Animals:** Trace amounts are detected in the brain, blood, and urine of mammals,
including humans.

**- Fungi and Toads:** Present in some fungi (Psilocybe species, etc) and certain toad
venoms.
**Appearance:** DMT is not visible in plants or
animals but is extracted as a powder or resin from plant material (Mimosa tenuiflora root bark
yields a reddish-brown extract, in Ayahuasca it is part of a dark, bitter liquid brew).

## History

Mimosa tenuiflora (also known as jurema or tepezcohuite) has been used by Indigenous peoples of northeastern Brazil in the sacred jurema ritual for centuries, where a DMT-containing drink called vinho de jurema is consumed for visionary and healing purposes. The Aztecs also reportedly used the plant, which they called tepezcohuite, primarily for wound healing and skin burns. In the modern era, Mimosa tenuiflora root bark became one of the most widely sourced DMT-containing plant materials in the global psychedelic community from the 2000s onward, used for ayahuasca analogs and DMT extraction.

## Connections

**Archetype:** [Acidhouse](../core-lore/archetypes.md#acidhouse)

**Ancestor:** [Mayan](../core-lore/ancestors/mayan.md)

**Tarot Card:** [Five of Pentacles](../core-lore/tarot-cards/five-of-pentacles.md)

**Paired With:** [DMT](dmt.md)

## Sources

- https://www.erowid.org/chemicals/dmt/dmt.shtml
- https://erowid.org/chemicals/dmt/dmt_info2.shtml
- https://pubchem.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/compound/N_N-Dimethyltryptamine
- [Mimosa tenuiflora - Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mimosa_tenuiflora)
- [N,N-Dimethyltryptamine - PubChem](https://pubchem.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/compound/6089)
- [N,N-Dimethyltryptamine - Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/N,N-Dimethyltryptamine)

════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════
SECTION: DRUG: Mmda
Source: drugs-detailed/mmda.md
════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════

# MMDA

## Effects & Properties

**Effects:** Euphoria, emotional openness, vivid sensory perception, mild
visual hallucinations.

**Natural Occurrence:** MMDA does not occur naturally. Primarily
used recreationally, it is used in psychedelic communities for its entactogenic and
sensory-enhancing effects, often compared to MDMA.

## History

MMDA (3-methoxy-4,5-methylenedioxyamphetamine) was first synthesized and pharmacologically explored by Alexander Shulgin in the 1960s, who described it in detail in his 1991 book PiHKAL. Shulgin noted its unique sensory-enhancing and empathogenic qualities, describing it as producing a "beautiful" experience distinct from both MDA and MDMA, with pronounced visual effects and emotional warmth. MMDA remained relatively obscure compared to its more famous relatives and is derived from the essential oil myristicin found in nutmeg, linking this synthetic psychedelic to one of the world's oldest spice-based intoxicants.

## Connections

**Archetype:** [Acidhouse](../core-lore/archetypes.md#acidhouse)

**Ancestor:** [Arabs](../core-lore/ancestors/arabs.md)

**Tarot Card:** [Nine of Pentacles](../core-lore/tarot-cards/nine-of-pentacles.md)

**Paired With:** [Nutmeg](nutmeg.md)

## Sources

- https://erowid.org/chemicals/mdma/mdma.shtml
- https://pubchem.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/compound/MMDA
- [MMDA (drug) - Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/MMDA_(drug))
- [Alexander Shulgin - Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alexander_Shulgin)
- [PiHKAL - Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/PiHKAL)
- [Myristicin - Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Myristicin)

<!-- @generated:backlinks-start -->

SECTION: DRUG: Mucuna Pruriens
Source: drugs-detailed/mucuna-pruriens.md
════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════

# Mucuna Pruriens

## Effects & Properties

**Effects:** Mild mood elevation, improved motivation, and enhanced mental
clarity due to increased dopamine. The effects are subtle.

**Natural Occurrence:** Native to tropical regions of Africa, Asia,
and Caribbean, this climbing legume grows in forests and disturbed areas. Traditionally used in
Ayurveda for nervous system disorders, male infertility, and vitality.
**Appearance:** Tropical vine growing from
3-18 meters tall, with green trifoliate leaves, purple or white flowers, and fuzzy brown seed pods
covered in irritating hairs. Dried seeds are dark brown to black, shiny, and ground into a
brownish powder.

## History

Mucuna pruriens (velvet bean) has been used in Ayurvedic medicine for over 3,000 years, described in ancient texts as a treatment for Kampavata (a condition resembling Parkinson's disease), male infertility, and general vitality. It is one of the richest natural sources of L-DOPA, the direct precursor to dopamine, which was confirmed by modern pharmacological research in the 1930s. The plant's L-DOPA content (3-6% in seeds) has attracted growing scientific interest for its potential in treating Parkinson's disease and as a natural mood enhancer, and it has become a popular supplement in the biohacking and nootropics communities.

## Connections

**Archetype:** [Acidhouse](../core-lore/archetypes.md#acidhouse)

**Ancestor:** [Hindu](../core-lore/ancestors/hindu.md)


## Sources

- https://www.erowid.org/plants/mucuna_pruriens/mucuna_pruriens.shtml
- https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mucuna_pruriens
- https://pubchem.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/compound/Levodopa
- [The Magic Velvet Bean of Mucuna pruriens (PMC)](https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC3942911/)
- [Levodopa in Mucuna pruriens and its degradation (Nature Scientific Reports)](https://www.nature.com/articles/srep11078)

SECTION: DRUG: Mushrooms
Source: drugs-detailed/mushrooms.md
════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════

# Mushrooms

## Effects & Properties

**Effects:** Visual and auditory hallucinations, kaleidoscopic variations in the
depth of vision, muscular relaxation and or tension, distortion of tactile sensations, lack of ability
to focus / concentrate, altered mood and perception of time.

**Natural Occurrence:** C12H17N2O4P (Psilocybin) is produced by
over 200 species of fungi, primarily in the genus Psilocybe. These mushrooms grow worldwide
in grasslands and pastures, forest and woodland, as well as tropical and or subtropical regions.
Common in South America, Southeast Asia, and Australia.
**Appearance:** Group 1 Psilocybes have a
cap from 2-7cm in diameter, viscid in wet weather but shiny when dry. Colour of the caps range
from whitish with a pale yellow centre at first, becoming entirely honey brown to reddish brown.
Often stains blue-green when old / injured. The stem grows up to 11cm tall, hollow, slender,
smooth, and slightly thickened downwards.
Group 2 Psilocybes have caps ranging from 1-5cm in diameter, with the color ranging from pale
brown to tawny orange, reddish brown, brownish yellow, or dark brown when older. Bruising
causes blue-green staining. The stems vary from 4-12cm tall, slender, and a silky fibrous
texture.

## History

Psilocybin mushrooms have been used ritually for thousands of years, with stone mushroom effigies from Guatemala and Mexico dating to at least 1000 BCE suggesting an ancient Mesoamerican mushroom cult. R. Gordon Wasson's 1957 Life magazine article "Seeking the Magic Mushroom," describing his experience with Maria Sabina in Oaxaca, ignited Western interest, and Albert Hofmann subsequently isolated and synthesized psilocybin in 1958. Magic mushrooms became a cornerstone of 1960s psychedelic counterculture, were classified as Schedule I in the US in 1970, and are now experiencing a clinical renaissance with FDA breakthrough therapy designation for psilocybin-assisted therapy for treatment-resistant depression.

## Connections

**Archetype:** [acidhouse](../core-lore/archetypes.md#acidhouse)

**Ancestor:** [Irish druids](../core-lore/ancestors/irish-druids.md), [Buddhist](../core-lore/ancestors/buddhist.md), [Sami](../core-lore/ancestors/sami.md)

**Tarot Card:** [Ten of Pentacles](../core-lore/tarot-cards/ten-of-pentacles.md)

## Sources

- https://www.erowid.org/psychoactives/faqs/faq_natural_high_australia.shtml#PITURI
- [Psilocybin - Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Psilocybin)
- [Psilocybin mushroom - Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Psilocybin_mushroom)
- [R. Gordon Wasson - Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/R._Gordon_Wasson)
- [Psilocybin - PubChem](https://pubchem.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/compound/Psilocybin)

SECTION: DRUG: Nicotine
Source: drugs-detailed/nicotine.md
════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════

# Nicotine

## Effects & Properties

**Effects:** Stimulation / relaxation, short-term use may enhance memory and
attention. Addiction upon long-term usage.

**Natural Occurrence:** Native to the Americas, tobacco has a long
history of use as a shamanic inebriant and stimulant. Nicotine is a naturally occurring stimulant
found in tobacco (Nicotiana spp.) and other solanaceous plants. At room temperature, it is only
oily liquid. As a constituent of tobacco, it has been used for many centuries in the Americas and
Australia, and is now sold in a variety of common products worldwide.
**Appearance:** Annual or bi-annual growing
1-3 meters tall with large sticky leaves.

## History

Tobacco use by Indigenous peoples of the Americas dates back thousands of years, employed in sacred ceremonies, healing rituals, and social gatherings. European colonizers adopted the plant after Columbus's voyages in the late 15th century, and tobacco quickly became a global commodity and one of the most traded crops in history. The mass-produced cigarette emerged in the late 19th century, and by the 20th century nicotine addiction was recognized as a major public health crisis, leading to widespread regulation and anti-smoking campaigns.

## Connections

**Archetype:** [Chicago Detroit](../core-lore/archetypes.md#chicago-detroit)

**Ancestor:** [Native American](../core-lore/ancestors/native-american.md), [Aboriginal](../core-lore/ancestors/aboriginal.md)

**Tarot Card:** [Page of Pentacles](../core-lore/tarot-cards/page-of-pentacles.md)

**Paired With:** [Tobacco](tobacco.md)

## Sources

- https://www.erowid.org/plants/tobacco/tobacco.shtml
- https://www.erowid.org/chemicals/nicotine/nicotine.shtml
- [Nicotine - Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nicotine)
- [Tobacco - Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tobacco)
- [Nicotiana tabacum - Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nicotiana_tabacum)
- [History of tobacco - Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/History_of_tobacco)
- [Nicotine | C10H14N2 - PubChem](https://pubchem.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/compound/Nicotine)

SECTION: DRUG: Nos
Source: drugs-detailed/nos.md
════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════

# NOS

## Effects & Properties

**Effects:** Dissociative anaesthetic gas.

**Natural Occurrence:** Nitrous Oxide is an anaesthetic gas best
known for its use in dentistry and as a whipped cream propellant. It is widely available and its
effects are short lasting. Technically it occurs naturally in the environment, produced in small
amounts through microbial processes, such as denitrification and nitrification, primarily in soil,
oceans, and wetlands.
**Appearance:** gas form.

## History

Nitrous oxide was first synthesized by English chemist Joseph Priestley in 1772, and its euphoric effects were famously demonstrated by Humphry Davy at "laughing gas" parties in the late 1790s at the Pneumatic Institution in Bristol. It was adopted as the first reliable dental and surgical anesthetic by Horace Wells in 1844. Nitrous oxide became a staple of rave and festival culture from the 1990s onward, sold from "hippie crack" balloons at events, prized for its brief but intense dissociative rush that pairs with electronic music.

## Connections

**Archetype:** [Acidhouse](../core-lore/archetypes.md#acidhouse)

**Ancestor:** [Pythia](../core-lore/ancestors/pythia.md)

**Tarot Card:** [Ten of Wands](../core-lore/tarot-cards/ten-of-wands.md)

**Paired With:** [Ethylene](ethylene.md)

## Sources

- https://www.erowid.org/chemicals/nitrous/nitrous.shtml
- https://www.epa.gov/ghgemissions/overview-greenhouse-gases#nitrous-oxide
- https://www.erowid.org/chemicals/nitrous/nitrous_timeline.php
- [Nitrous oxide - Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nitrous_oxide)
- [Nitrous oxide (medication) - Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nitrous_oxide_(medication))
- [Horace Wells - Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Horace_Wells)
- [Humphry Davy - Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Humphry_Davy)
- [Pneumatic Institution - Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pneumatic_Institution)
- [A Brief History of Nitrous Oxide (N2O) Use in Neuropsychiatry (PMC)](https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC6637098/)

════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════
SECTION: DRUG: Nutmeg
Source: drugs-detailed/nutmeg.md
════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════

# Nutmeg

## Effects & Properties

**Effects:** Deliriant, mild euphoria, relaxation, and occasional visual
distortions. Effects are subtle and often described as cannabis-like.

**Natural Occurrence:** Native to the Moluccas (spice island) in
Indonesia, this tree produces nutmeg seeds and mace (seed aril).
**Appearance:** Brown, oval seeds, encased
in a red lacy mace aril within a hard shell. Ground nutmeg is a light brown powder with a warm
spicy aroma.

## History

Nutmeg (Myristica fragrans) originated in the Banda Islands of Indonesia and was one of the most coveted spices in the world for centuries, driving European colonial wars including the Dutch massacre of the Bandanese people in 1621 to secure a monopoly. Its psychoactive properties were documented by medieval Arab physicians, and the 12th-century German mystic Hildegard von Bingen described nutmeg's mood-altering effects. Nutmeg intoxication has been reported throughout history, notably in prisons and among those without access to other substances, and the spice was famously explored by Malcolm X during his incarceration, as described in his autobiography.

## Connections

**Archetype:** [Acidhouse](../core-lore/archetypes.md#acidhouse)

**Ancestor:** [Arabs](../core-lore/ancestors/arabs.md)

**Tarot Card:** [The Moon](../core-lore/tarot-cards/the-moon.md)

**Paired With:** [MMDA](mmda.md)

## Sources

- https://erowid.org/plants/nutmeg/nutmeg.shtml
- https://pubchem.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/compound/Myristicin
- https://www.webmd.com/vitamins/ai/ingredientmono-788/nutmeg-and-mace
- [Nutmeg - Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nutmeg)
- [Myristicin - Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Myristicin)
- [Dutch conquest of the Banda Islands - Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dutch_conquest_of_the_Banda_Islands)
- [Myristica fragrans - Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Myristica_fragrans)

════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════
SECTION: DRUG: Nymphaea Caerulea
Source: drugs-detailed/nymphaea-caerulea.md
════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════

# Nymphaea Caerulea

## Effects & Properties

**Effects:** Mild sedation, relaxation, and a subtle euphoria. It induces
calmness, enhances mood and senses without hallucinations.

**Natural Occurrence:** Native to the Nile River region and East
Africa, this aquatic plant grows in ponds and wetlands.
**Appearance:** Large round green leaves
floating on water, with vibrant blue to purple flowers and yellow at the centers, as well as
rhizomatous roots. Dried flowers are blue to grayish-blue with a mild floral odor.

## History

Nymphaea caerulea (the blue Egyptian lotus) was sacred in ancient Egyptian civilization, appearing extensively in art, temple decorations, and funerary practices from as early as 3000 BCE, where it symbolized creation, rebirth, and the sun. It was likely consumed as a wine infusion during religious ceremonies and social gatherings for its mildly sedative and euphoric effects. The flower was rediscovered by Western ethnobotanists in the late 20th century and has since gained a following in the modern herbal and psychoactive plant communities.

## Connections

**Archetype:** [Chicago Detroit](../core-lore/archetypes.md#chicago-detroit)

**Ancestor:** [Greek](../core-lore/ancestors/greek.md)

**Tarot Card:** [Queen of Swords](../core-lore/tarot-cards/queen-of-swords.md)

**Paired With:** [Poppers](poppers.md)

## Sources

- https://erowid.org/plants/lotus/lotus.shtml
- https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC5638439/
- https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nymphaea_nouchali_var._caerulea
- [Nymphaea cults in ancient Egypt and the New World: a lesson in empirical pharmacology (PMC)](https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC1079300/)
- [Chemical Composition, Market Survey, and Safety Assessment of Blue Lotus Extracts (PMC)](https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC10609367/)
- [Nuciferine - Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nuciferine)
- [Egyptian lotus - Britannica](https://www.britannica.com/plant/Egyptian-lotus)

## Miberas with this Drug

════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════
SECTION: DRUG: Ololiuqui
Source: drugs-detailed/ololiuqui.md
════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════

# Ololiuqui

## Effects & Properties

**Effects:** Mild to moderate visual hallucinations, calmness, and dream-like
states.

**Natural Occurrence:** Native to Central and South America, this
perennial vine grows in tropical and subtropical regions. Traditionally used by Mesoamerican
cultures (like the Aztecs) in spiritual and shamanic rituals for divination and healing, often as a
seed infusion. Recreationally, ololiuqui seeds are consumed for their psychedelic effects.
**Appearance:** Climbing vine with
heart-shaped green leaves, white to pale purple trumpet-shaped flowers, and small brown to
black round seeds. Dried seeds are hard, dark, and bitter.

## History

Ololiuqui (Turbina corymbosa, formerly Rivea corymbosa) was one of the most important ritual plants of pre-Columbian Mesoamerica, used by the Aztecs, Mazatecs, and other peoples as a divinatory sacrament, with detailed descriptions in 16th-century Spanish colonial texts including those by Francisco Hernandez (1570). Its active compounds, ergine (LSA) and related ergot alkaloids, were identified by Albert Hofmann in 1960, establishing a remarkable chemical link between an ancient Mesoamerican sacrament and modern LSD. Ololiuqui use persists among indigenous communities in Oaxaca, Mexico, where curanderos continue to employ the seeds for healing and divination.

## Connections

**Archetype:** [Acidhouse](../core-lore/archetypes.md#acidhouse)

**Ancestor:** [Mayan](../core-lore/ancestors/mayan.md)

**Tarot Card:** [Page of Wands](../core-lore/tarot-cards/page-of-wands.md)

**Paired With:** [LSD](lsd.md)

## Sources

- https://www.erowid.org/plants/ololiuqui/ololiuqui.shtml
- https://pubchem.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/compound/Ergine
- https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ipomoea_corymbosa
- [Ergine (d-lysergic acid amide) - Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ergine)

<!-- @generated:backlinks-start -->

════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════
SECTION: DRUG: Peyote
Source: drugs-detailed/peyote.md
════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════

# Peyote

## Effects & Properties

**Effects:** Psychedelic, vivid visual hallucinations, heightened emotional
sensitivity.

**Natural Occurrence:** Native to the Chihuahuan Desert (southern
Texas, northern Mexico), this cactus contains mescaline in its crowns or “buttons” and grows in
arid, rocky soils, and is harvested for ceremonial use.
**Appearance:** Small, rounded cactus
between 2-5cm in diameter, with gray-green to bluish-green flesh, with fuzzy tufts instead of
spines, and small pink or white flowers. Fresh or dried peyote “buttons” are brownish or
grayish-green and bitter.

## History

Peyote (Lophophora williamsii) has been used sacramentally by Indigenous peoples of Mexico and the American Southwest for at least 5,700 years, based on radiocarbon dating of specimens found in Shumla Cave, Texas. It was central to the spiritual practices of the Huichol (Wixaritari), Tarahumara (Raramuri), and other Mesoamerican peoples long before the founding of the Native American Church in 1918, which formalized peyote ritual as a syncretic religion combining Indigenous and Christian elements. The Religious Freedom Restoration Act of 1994 protected peyote use for Native American Church members, and Aldous Huxley's 1954 book "The Doors of Perception" describing his mescaline experience brought peyote into mainstream Western awareness.

## Connections

**Archetype:** [Freetekno](../core-lore/archetypes.md#freetekno)

**Ancestor:** [Native American](../core-lore/ancestors/native-american.md)

**Tarot Card:** [King of Cups](../core-lore/tarot-cards/king-of-cups.md)

**Paired With:** [2C-B](2c-b.md)

## Sources

- https://www.erowid.org/plants/peyote/peyote.shtml
- https://www.erowid.org/plants/peyote/peyote_faq.shtml
- [Peyote - Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Peyote)
- [Mescaline - Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mescaline)
- [Mescaline - PubChem](https://pubchem.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/compound/Mescaline)
- [Native American Church - Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Native_American_Church)
- [The Doors of Perception - Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Doors_of_Perception)
- [Prehistoric peyote use: alkaloid analysis and radiocarbon dating - PubMed](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/15990261/)
- [American Indian Religious Freedom Act - Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/American_Indian_Religious_Freedom_Act)

════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════
SECTION: DRUG: Piracetam
Source: drugs-detailed/piracetam.md
════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════

# Piracetam

## Effects & Properties

**Effects:** Produces subtle cognitive enhancement, such as improved
attention, verbal fluency, and mental clarity. Effects are often cumulative, requiring days to
weeks for noticeable benefits.

**Natural Occurrence:** Piracetam does not occur naturally and
was first synthesized in 1964 by UCB Pharma in Belgium.

## History

Piracetam was synthesized in 1964 by Romanian chemist Corneliu Giurgea at the Belgian pharmaceutical company UCB, and he coined the term "nootropic" (from the Greek nous for mind and trepein for to bend) to describe its class of cognitive-enhancing compounds. It was the first nootropic drug ever developed, designed to enhance memory and learning without stimulant side effects. Piracetam became widely prescribed in Europe and Russia for cognitive decline and is available over the counter in many countries, pioneering the modern nootropics movement that has since expanded into Silicon Valley biohacking culture.

## Connections

**Archetype:** [Chicago Detroit](../core-lore/archetypes.md#chicago-detroit)

**Ancestor:** [Hindu](../core-lore/ancestors/hindu.md)

**Tarot Card:** [Ace of Swords](../core-lore/tarot-cards/ace-of-swords.md)

**Paired With:** [Brahmi](brahmi.md)

## Sources

- https://pubchem.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/compound/Piracetam
- https://www.drugs.com/medical-answers/piracetam-3570384/
- https://medlineplus.gov/druginfo/meds/a604001.html
- [Piracetam - Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Piracetam)
- [Corneliu E. Giurgea - Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Corneliu_E._Giurgea)
- [Nootropic - Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nootropic)

════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════
SECTION: DRUG: Pituri
Source: drugs-detailed/pituri.md
════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════

# Pituri

## Effects & Properties

**Effects:** Stimulant, narcotic, deliriant (in large quantities).

**Natural Occurrence:** Used by Aboriginal Australians and traded
across Australia. It grows in the arid regions of central Australia from WA, across NT and SA to
Qld and NSW.
**Appearance:** A small tree or shrub about 3
meters high with narrow linear leaves up to 15 cm long. Its flowers have a broad bell-shaped
white corolla, with a purple-striped tube, and five lobes. The fruit is a black 6mm long berry that
contains two seeds in a dark pulp.

## History

Pituri (Duboisia hopwoodii) has been used by Aboriginal Australians for thousands of years, making it one of the oldest continuously used psychoactive substances on the planet. It was chewed as a stimulant mixed with alkaline wood ash (to enhance nicotine absorption) and was one of the most valuable trade items in pre-colonial Aboriginal trade networks, transported along "pituri roads" stretching thousands of kilometers across the Australian interior. European settlers documented pituri use from the 1860s onward, and the plant remains culturally significant to Indigenous communities in central Australia.

## Connections

**Archetype:** [Chicago Detroit](../core-lore/archetypes.md#chicago-detroit)

**Ancestor:** [Aboriginal](../core-lore/ancestors/aboriginal.md)

**Tarot Card:** [The Magician](../core-lore/tarot-cards/the-magician.md)

**Paired With:** [Chewing Tobacco](chewing-tobacco.md)

## Sources

- https://www.erowid.org/psychoactives/faqs/faq_natural_high_australia.shtml#PITURI
- [Pituri - Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pituri)
- [Duboisia hopwoodii - Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Duboisia_hopwoodii)
- [Nicotine - Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nicotine)
- [The pituri story: a review of the historical literature surrounding traditional Australian Aboriginal use of nicotine in Central Australia - PMC](https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC2944156/)

════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════
SECTION: DRUG: Poppers
Source: drugs-detailed/poppers.md
════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════

# Poppers

## Effects & Properties

**Effects:** Rapid, short-lived “rush” of euphoria, warmth, and
lightheadedness when inhaled. Enhances sensory perception, particularly tactile and sexual
sensations, and induces a brief sense of exhilaration. Effects onset within seconds and last
between 1-5 minutes.

**Natural Occurrence:** Poppers does not occur naturally, it is
synthesized from amyl alcohol and sodium nitrite in laboratory settings.

## History

Amyl nitrite was first synthesized by French chemist Antoine Balard in 1844, and its vasodilating properties were quickly applied to treating angina. By the 1960s and 1970s, poppers became widely adopted in gay club culture, particularly at discotheques and bathhouses, for their ability to enhance sensory experience and physical sensation. They became synonymous with the gay liberation movement and disco era, carried through into house music and rave culture of the 1980s-90s, and remain one of the most iconic substances associated with LGBTQ+ nightlife and dance culture.

## Connections

**Archetype:** [Chicago Detroit](../core-lore/archetypes.md#chicago-detroit)

**Ancestor:** **Swag Score:** 3

**Tarot Card:** [Page of Swords](../core-lore/tarot-cards/page-of-swords.md)

**Paired With:** [Nymphaea Caerulea](nymphaea-caerulea.md)

## Sources

- https://erowid.org/chemicals/inhalants/inhalants.shtml
- https://pubchem.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/compound/Amyl-nitrite
- https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Poppers
- [Amyl nitrite - Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Amyl_nitrite)
- [Lauder Brunton - Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lauder_Brunton)
- [T. Lauder Brunton and amyl nitrite: a Victorian vasodilator (Circulation)](https://www.ahajournals.org/doi/pdf/10.1161/01.cir.74.2.222)
- [From Medicine to Moral Panic: The History of Poppers (History Hit)](https://www.historyhit.com/from-medicine-to-moral-panic-the-history-of-poppers/)

════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════
SECTION: DRUG: Psilacetin
Source: drugs-detailed/psilacetin.md
════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════

# Psilacetin

## Effects & Properties

**Effects:** Vivid visual and auditory hallucinations, euphoria, and altered
perception of time and space.

**Natural Occurrence:** Psilacetin is a synthetic compound and
does not occur naturally. Used primarily recreationally for psychedelic experiences in spiritual or
social settings.

## History

Psilacetin (4-AcO-DMT, or O-acetylpsilocin) was first synthesized by Albert Hofmann and Franz Troxler at Sandoz Laboratories in Switzerland in 1963 as part of their research into psilocybin analogs. It remained relatively obscure for decades until the rise of the online research chemical market in the 2000s, where it was sold as a legal psilocybin prodrug that converts to psilocin in the body. Psilacetin became popular in psychedelic communities for its mushroom-like effects and more consistent dosing compared to natural psilocybin mushrooms, and it occupies a legal gray area in many countries.

## Connections

**Archetype:** [Acidhouse](../core-lore/archetypes.md#acidhouse)

**Ancestor:** [Irish Druids](../core-lore/ancestors/irish-druids.md), [Buddhist](../core-lore/ancestors/buddhist.md), [Sami](../core-lore/ancestors/sami.md)

**Tarot Card:** [The High Priestess](../core-lore/tarot-cards/the-high-priestess.md)

## Sources

- https://www.drugs.com/illicit/psilacetin.html
- https://erowid.org/chemicals/4_aco_dmt/4_aco_dmt.shtml
- [4-AcO-DMT - Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/4-AcO-DMT)
- [In vivo validation of psilacetin as a prodrug - Frontiers in Psychiatry](https://www.frontiersin.org/journals/psychiatry/articles/10.3389/fpsyt.2023.1303365/full)
- [Tentative identification of in vitro metabolites of O-acetylpsilocin - PubMed](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/35312166/)

════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════
SECTION: DRUG: Psychotria Viridis
Source: drugs-detailed/psychotria-viridis.md
════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════

# Psychotria Viridis

## Effects & Properties

**Effects:** Vivid hallucinations, altered perception of time and space, and
emotional introspection. The effects are rapid and intense. Risks include psychological distress,
and a rare psychotic episode in predisposed individuals.

**Natural Occurrence:** Native to Central and South America, the
shrub contains DMT in its leaves at concentrations of 0.1–0.61% by dry weight, with higher
levels in the morning. It grows in humid rainforest, often in fertile, limestone-rich soils up to 150
meters altitude.
**Appearance:** The plant is a shrub between
1,5 to 5 meters tall, with glossy dark green elliptic leaves, small white flowers, and red to purple
berries. Dried leaves are grayish or reddish brown.

## History

Psychotria viridis (chacruna) has been used by Indigenous Amazonian peoples for centuries as the primary DMT-containing ingredient in ayahuasca brews, combined with the MAO-inhibiting Banisteriopsis caapi vine. The plant's role in ayahuasca was first documented by Western ethnobotanists in the mid-20th century, notably by Richard Evans Schultes and later by the Ethnobotanical Stewardship Council. Chacruna has become central to the global ayahuasca movement that emerged from the 1990s onward, with ayahuasca retreat centers proliferating across South America and beyond, attracting spiritual seekers and researchers studying its potential for treating depression and PTSD.

## Connections

**Archetype:** [Freetekno](../core-lore/archetypes.md#freetekno)

**Ancestor:** [Native American](../core-lore/ancestors/native-american.md), [Mayan](../core-lore/ancestors/mayan.md)

**Tarot Card:** [Page of Cups](../core-lore/tarot-cards/page-of-cups.md)

**Paired With:** [Datura](datura.md)

## Sources

- https://erowid.org/plants/psychotria/psychotria.shtml
- https://pubchem.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/compound/Dimethyltryptamine
- https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Psychotria_viridis
- [Ayahuasca - Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ayahuasca)
- [Banisteriopsis caapi - Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Banisteriopsis_caapi)
- [Richard Evans Schultes - Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Richard_Evans_Schultes)
- [N,N-Dimethyltryptamine - Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/N,N-Dimethyltryptamine)

════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════
SECTION: DRUG: Sakae Na
Source: drugs-detailed/sakae-na.md
════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════

# Sakae Na

## Effects & Properties

**Effects:** Mild to moderate stimulation, increased alertness, focus, and
sociability, often compared to a caffeine-like “rush”.

**Natural Occurrence:** Native to Southeast Asia (Vietnam,
Cambodia, Laos, Myanmar, Thailand), the tree grows in wet, open areas like riverbanks.
Traditionally, Sakae Na leaves are chewed fresh or dried, brewed as tea, or smoked for energy
and pain relief, particularly in Thailand and Myanmar where it serves as a kratom substitute due
to the kratom ban.
**Appearance:** The tree grows up to 10
meters tall, has elliptic or obovate green leaves, yellowish-white flowers, and brownish-red
four-angled seeds. Dried leaves are greenish-brown to brown and often ground into brown
powder.

## History

Sakae Na (Combretum quadrangulare) has been used in traditional medicine throughout Southeast Asia, particularly in Thailand, Myanmar, Cambodia, and Laos, for centuries as a treatment for fever, intestinal parasites, and general fatigue. It gained particular significance in Thailand after kratom was banned in 1943, as local communities turned to Sakae Na leaves as a legal substitute for their mildly stimulant and pain-relieving effects. The plant remains relatively obscure outside Southeast Asia but has attracted growing international interest from the late 2010s onward among kratom users seeking legal alternatives.

## Connections

**Archetype:** [Milady](../core-lore/archetypes.md#milady)

**Ancestor:** [Thai](../core-lore/ancestors/thai.md)


## Sources

- https://erowid.org/plants/sakae_naa/
- https://pubchem.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/compound/Combretol
- https://kratomtimes.com/kratom-vs-sakae-naa/
- [Combretum quadrangulare - Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Combretum_quadrangulare)
- [Flavones from Combretum quadrangulare and Their Alpha-Glucosidase Inhibitory Activity (PMC)](https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC8123651/)

════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════
SECTION: DRUG: Sassafras
Source: drugs-detailed/sassafras.md
════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════

# Sassafras

## Effects & Properties

**Effects:** Stimulant, anti-inflammatory, metabolite, relaxation.

**Natural Occurrence:** Traditionally, sassafras root bark or leaves
were used in Native American and early American medicine for fever, colds, and rheumatism, as
well as a flavoring agent. Found in the root bark, leaves, and wood of this deciduous tree native
to eastern North America.
**Appearance:** Plants with green lobed
leaves, yellow flowers, and brownish root bark. Dried root bark appears as reddish-brown to
dark brown

## History

Sassafras (Sassafras albidum) was used extensively by Native American peoples for medicinal teas, poultices, and as a food flavoring long before European contact. Spanish explorers brought sassafras back to Europe in the 16th century, where it was marketed as a cure-all and became one of the first major exports from the New World. Sassafras root bark contains safrole, which was identified in the 20th century as a precursor chemical for synthesizing MDA and MDMA, leading to its regulation under the DEA's List I chemicals in the 1990s, linking this ancient medicinal plant directly to modern rave pharmacology.

## Connections

**Archetype:** [Milady](../core-lore/archetypes.md#milady)

**Ancestor:** [Native American](../core-lore/ancestors/native-american.md)

**Tarot Card:** [Three of Cups](../core-lore/tarot-cards/three-of-cups.md)

**Paired With:** [MDMA](mdma.md), [MDA](mda.md)

## Sources

- https://pubchem.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/compound/Safrole
- https://erowid.org/plants/sassafras/sassafras.shtml
- https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Safrole
- [Sassafras albidum - Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sassafras_albidum)
- [Sassafras - Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sassafras)
- [DEA Diversion Control: Safrole and Sassafras Oil Advisory](https://www.deadiversion.usdoj.gov/chem_prog/advisories/safrole.html)

════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════
SECTION: DRUG: Scopolamine
Source: drugs-detailed/scopolamine.md
════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════

# Scopolamine

## Effects & Properties

**Effects:** Delirium, hallucinations, confusion, and disorienting. Physically
can cause dry mouth, blurred vision, pupil dilation, rapid heartbeat, urinary retention,
constipation, and hyperthermia.

**Natural Occurrence:** Scopolamine occurs naturally in Datura and
Henbane.

- Datura (Datura stramonium, D. innoxia, D. metel): Found in all plant parts, with highest
concentrations in seeds and leaves. Datura species are weeds growing in temperate
and tropical regions worldwide, often in disturbed soils.

**- Henbane (Hyoscyamus niger):** Native to Europe, North Africa, and Asia, scopolamine is
present in seeds and leaves, alongside hyoscyamine. It thrives in disturbed soils and
wastelands.

- Belladona, a 1-2 meter tall perennial herb that produces small red to black berries.
- Datura has large, coarse green leaves, trumpet-shaped white or purple flowers, and
spiky seed pods.

- Henbane has dull green, hairy leaves, yellowish flowers with purple veins, and small
seed capsules.

- Belladona, a 1-2 meter tall perennial herb that produces small red to black berries.

## History

Scopolamine was first isolated from Scopolia plants by German chemist Albert Ladenburg in 1880, and it has been used in various Solanaceae plants (Datura, henbane, belladonna) since antiquity for ritual and medicinal purposes. It was infamously used as a "truth serum" by police and intelligence agencies in the early 20th century, and the CIA explored it during Project MKUltra in the 1950s. In modern times, scopolamine gained notoriety as "devil's breath" (burundanga) in Colombia, where criminals allegedly use it to render victims compliant, while medically it remains widely used as a patch for motion sickness.

## Connections

**Archetype:** [Freetekno](../core-lore/archetypes.md#freetekno)

**Ancestor:** [Greek](../core-lore/ancestors/greek.md), [Arabs](../core-lore/ancestors/arabs.md)

**Tarot Card:** [Five of Swords](../core-lore/tarot-cards/five-of-swords.md)

**Paired With:** [Henbane](henbane.md)

## Sources

- https://erowid.org/plants/datura/datura.shtml
- https://www.erowid.org/plants/belladonna/belladonna.shtml
- https://www.drugs.com/mtm/scopolamine.html
- [Scopolamine - Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Scopolamine)
- [Albert Ladenburg - Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Albert_Ladenburg)
- [Truth serum - Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Truth_serum)
- [Scopolamine - StatPearls, NCBI Bookshelf](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK554397/)
- [Scopolamine Transdermal Patch - MedlinePlus](https://medlineplus.gov/druginfo/meds/a682509.html)
- [Million dollar ride: Crime committed during involuntary scopolamine intoxication - PMC](https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC5429053/)

════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════
SECTION: DRUG: Sertraline
Source: drugs-detailed/sertraline.md
════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════

# Sertraline

## Effects & Properties

**Effects:** Treats major depressive disorder, generalized anxiety disorder,
panic disorder, social anxiety disorder, obsessive-compulsive disorder, and post-traumatic stress
disorder. It may also be used for premenstrual dysphoric disorder. Typically improves mood,
reduces anxiety, and fewer intrusive thoughts after 4-8 weeks of treatment (with doses of
50-200mg/day orally). It gradually stabilizes mood by enhancing serotonin signaling.
Physically can cause nausea, diarrhea, insomnia, headache, fatigue, and sexual dysfunction.

**Natural Occurrence:** Sertraline does not occur naturally, it is
manufactured in laboratories through chemical synthesis.

## History

Sertraline was developed by Pfizer chemists Reinhard Sarges and Kenneth Koe in the early 1980s as part of the new wave of selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs). It received FDA approval in 1991 and was marketed as Zoloft, quickly becoming one of the most prescribed antidepressants in the world. By the 2000s, sertraline had become a cultural touchstone of modern mental health treatment, prescribed to millions for depression, anxiety, OCD, and PTSD, and its ubiquity reflects the broader pharmaceutical revolution in how society addresses emotional suffering.

## Connections

**Archetype:** [Freetekno](../core-lore/archetypes.md#freetekno)

**Ancestor:** [Greek](../core-lore/ancestors/greek.md)

**Tarot Card:** [Four of Cups](../core-lore/tarot-cards/four-of-cups.md)

**Paired With:** [St. John's Wort](st-johns-wort.md)

## Sources

- https://pubchem.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/compound/Sertraline
- https://www.drugs.com/sertraline.html
- https://medlineplus.gov/druginfo/meds/a697048.html
- [Sertraline - Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sertraline)
- [Selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor - Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Selective_serotonin_reuptake_inhibitor)
- [Sertraline - StatPearls (NCBI Bookshelf)](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK547689/)

<!-- @generated:backlinks-start -->
## Miberas with this Drug

════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════
SECTION: DRUG: Shroom Tea
Source: drugs-detailed/shroom-tea.md
════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════

# Shroom Tea

## Effects & Properties

**Effects:** Visual and auditory hallucinations, kaleidoscopic variations in the
depth of vision, muscular relaxation and or tension, distortion of tactile sensations, lack of ability
to focus / concentrate, altered mood and perception of time.

**Natural Occurrence:** C12H17N2O4P (Psilocybin) is produced by over 200 species of fungi, primarily in the genus Psilocybe. These mushrooms grow worldwide
in grasslands and pastures, forest and woodland, as well as tropical and or subtropical regions.
Common in South America, Southeast Asia, and Australia.
**Appearance:** Group 1 Psilocybes have a
cap from 2-7cm in diameter, viscid in wet weather but shiny when dry. Colour of the caps range
from whitish with a pale yellow centre at first, becoming entirely honey brown to reddish brown.
Often stains blue-green when old / injured. The stem grows up to 11cm tall, hollow, slender,
smooth, and slightly thickened downwards.
Group 2 Psilocybes have caps ranging from 1-5cm in diameter, with the color ranging from pale
brown to tawny orange, reddish brown, brownish yellow, or dark brown when older. Bruising
causes blue-green staining. The stems vary from 4-12cm tall, slender, and a silky fibrous
texture.

## History

Psilocybin mushroom tea has roots in Mesoamerican cultures, where the Aztecs and Mazatec peoples consumed psilocybin mushrooms (called teonanacatl, "flesh of the gods") in sacred rituals dating back at least 2,000 years. R. Gordon Wasson brought Western attention to their use after participating in a Mazatec ceremony with curandera Maria Sabina in Oaxaca, Mexico in 1955. The modern practice of brewing mushrooms as tea became popular in psychedelic counterculture from the 1960s onward, offering a gentler onset than eating dried mushrooms, and remains a common preparation method in contemporary psychedelic and rave-adjacent communities.

## Connections

**Archetype:** [Acidhouse](../core-lore/archetypes.md#acidhouse)

**Ancestor:** [Greek](../core-lore/ancestors/greek.md)

**Tarot Card:** [Six of Pentacles](../core-lore/tarot-cards/six-of-pentacles.md)

**Paired With:** [Kykeon](kykeon.md)

## Sources

- https://www.erowid.org/psychoactives/faqs/faq_natural_high_australia.shtml#PITURI
- [Psilocybin - Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Psilocybin)
- [Psilocybin mushroom - Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Psilocybin_mushroom)
- [Psilocybin | C12H17N2O4P - PubChem](https://pubchem.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/compound/psilocybine)
- [Maria Sabina - Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mar%C3%ADa_Sabina)
- [Aztec use of entheogens - Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Aztec_use_of_entheogens)
- [List of psilocybin mushroom species - Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_psilocybin_mushroom_species)
- [Psilocybin: from ancient magic to modern medicine - PubMed](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/32398764/)

SECTION: DRUG: Sildenafil
Source: drugs-detailed/sildenafil.md
════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════

# Sildenafil

## Effects & Properties

**Effects:** Increased cGMP levels, smooth muscle relaxation, enhanced
bloodflow. In ED, it facilitates penile erection by improving blood flow in response to sexual
stimulation. In PAH, it reduces pulmonary artery pressure by relaxing blood vessels in the lungs.

**Natural Occurrence:** Sildenafil does not occur naturally. It was
developed by Pfizer through chemical synthesis.

## History

Sildenafil was originally developed by Pfizer scientists Andrew Bell, David Brown, and Nicholas Terrett in the UK during the late 1980s as a treatment for hypertension and angina. During clinical trials, researchers noticed a remarkable side effect of sustained penile erections, leading to its repurposing. Marketed as Viagra and approved by the FDA in March 1998, it became one of the fastest-selling pharmaceutical products in history and fundamentally changed the treatment of erectile dysfunction worldwide.

## Connections

**Archetype:** [Chicago Detroit](../core-lore/archetypes.md#chicago-detroit)

**Ancestor:** [Gabon](../core-lore/ancestors/gabon.md)

**Tarot Card:** [Seven of Cups](../core-lore/tarot-cards/seven-of-cups.md)

**Paired With:** [Yohimbe](yohimbe.md)

## Sources

- https://www.chemspider.com/Chemical-Structure.5023.html
- https://www.drugs.com/monograph/sildenafil-erectile-dysfunction.html
- [Sildenafil - Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sildenafil)
- [Sildenafil (C22H30N6O4S) - PubChem](https://pubchem.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/compound/Sildenafil)
- [Sildenafil - StatPearls (NCBI)](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK558978/)
- [FDA Approves Viagra, March 27, 1998 - HISTORY](https://www.history.com/this-day-in-history/fda-approves-viagra)
- [Made Up in Britain: Viagra (Bell, Brown and Terrett 1991)](https://madeupinbritain.uk/Viagra)

════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════
SECTION: DRUG: Sober
Source: drugs-detailed/sober.md
════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════

# Sober

## Effects & Properties

**Effects:** Promotes feelings of happiness, production of melatonin,
increased appetite, and mitigates anxiety and stress.

**Natural Occurrence:** **Appearance:**

## History

Serotonin was first identified in 1948 by Maurice Rapport, Arda Green, and Irvine Page at the Cleveland Clinic, who isolated it from blood serum and named it for its vasoconstrictive properties (serum tonic). Its role as a neurotransmitter in the brain was established in the 1950s by Betty Twarog and Irvine Page. The understanding that endogenous serotonin regulates mood, sleep, appetite, and well-being has been foundational to modern psychiatry, leading to the development of SSRIs in the 1980s and reshaping how humanity understands the neurochemistry of baseline contentment and emotional resilience.

## Connections

**Archetype:** [Milady](../core-lore/archetypes.md#milady)

**Ancestor:** [Mongolian](../core-lore/ancestors/mongolian.md)

**Tarot Card:** [Ace of Pentacles](../core-lore/tarot-cards/ace-of-pentacles.md)

**Paired With:** [Euphoria](euphoria.md), [Clear Pill](clear-pill.md)

## Sources

- https://www.webmd.com/depression/video/video-serotonin-effects
- https://www.healthline.com/health/mental-health/serotonin
- [Serotonin - Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Serotonin) — discovery in 1948 by Maurice Rapport, Arda Green, and Irvine Page at Cleveland Clinic; named from serum + tonic; role as neurotransmitter
- [Maurice M. Rapport - Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Maurice_M._Rapport) — isolation of serotonin from blood serum
- [Betty Twarog - Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Betty_Twarog) — first discovery of serotonin in mammalian brain (1952-1953)
- [Development and discovery of SSRI drugs - Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Development_and_discovery_of_SSRI_drugs) — SSRI development in the 1980s

════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════
SECTION: DRUG: St Johns Wort
Source: drugs-detailed/st-johns-wort.md
════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════

# St John's Wort

## Effects & Properties

**Effects:** Mood elevation, reduced anxiety, and improved emotional
well-being. Effects are subtle, requiring consistent use over weeks for noticeable benefits.

**Natural Occurrence:** Native to Europe, Asia, and North Africa,
this perennial herb grows in temperate regions, often as a weed in meadows or roadsides. St.
John’s Wort is used in herbal supplements for depression and mood disorders and has a long
history in traditional European medicine for wound healing and mental health.
**Appearance:** The plant has a bushy
structure with perforated leaves, yellow flowers, and green leaves. Dried St. John’s Wort
appears as yellowish-green to brownish herbal material with a slightly bitter, earthy odor.

## History

St. John's Wort (Hypericum perforatum) has been used medicinally since ancient Greece, where Hippocrates and Dioscorides recommended it for wound healing and nervous conditions around the 1st century CE. Its name derives from its traditional harvest on St. John's Day (June 24), and medieval Europeans believed it could ward off evil spirits and melancholy. Modern clinical trials beginning in the 1990s, particularly in Germany where it was already the most prescribed antidepressant, demonstrated its efficacy for mild to moderate depression, making it one of the best-studied herbal medicines and a bridge between ancient herbalism and modern psychopharmacology.

## Connections

**Archetype:** [Freetekno](../core-lore/archetypes.md#freetekno)

**Ancestor:** [Greek](../core-lore/ancestors/greek.md)


## Sources

- https://erowid.org/herbs/sjwort/sjwort.shtml
- https://pubchem.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/compound/Hypericin
- https://www.webmd.com/vitamins/ai/ingredientmono-329/st-johns-wort
- [Hypericum perforatum - Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hypericum_perforatum)
- [Hypericin - Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hypericin)
- [Hypericin - PubChem (CID 3663)](https://pubchem.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/compound/hypericin)
- [St John's wort for major depression - Cochrane/PMC](https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC7032678/)
- [Medical Attributes of St. John's Wort - NCBI Bookshelf](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK92750/)
- [St. John's Wort - NCCIH](https://www.nccih.nih.gov/health/st-johns-wort)

════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════
SECTION: DRUG: Sugarcane
Source: drugs-detailed/sugarcane.md
════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════

# Sugarcane

## Effects & Properties

**Effects:** Increased energy. Rapidly increasing blood sugar due to its high
glycemic index, causes a quick rise in blood glucose, stimulating insulin release. Moderate
consumption is generally safe, but excessive intake is linked to weight gain, type 2 diabetes,
dental caries, and cardiovascular risks. Overconsumption can also lead to obesity, insulin
resistance, and metabolic syndrome. Dental caries are also a significant concern due to
sucrose’s fermentation by oral bacteria.

**Natural Occurrence:** Sugarcane stalks contain 12-20% sucrose
by weight, making it a primary commercial source. The plant, native to Southeast Asia, is
cultivated to tropical regions like Brazil, India, and the Caribbean. In sugarcane, sucrose is
stored in the stalks, then refined to isolate it as white or brown sugar.
**Appearance:** Juicy, fibrous stalks, which are
green to brownish and segmented. Sugarcane juice is a cloudy, sweet liquid (10-15% sucrose)
that turns brownish when processed into molasses or raw sugar.

## History

Sugarcane was first domesticated in New Guinea around 8000 BCE and spread to India, where the process of crystallizing sugar was developed around 350 CE. Arab traders brought sugar production techniques to the Mediterranean, and European colonial powers established massive sugar plantations in the Caribbean and Americas from the 16th century onward, fueling the transatlantic slave trade. Sugar became one of the most influential commodities in world history, transforming global economies, diets, and public health, and its overconsumption is now linked to the modern epidemics of obesity and diabetes.

## Connections

**Archetype:** [Chicago Detroit](../core-lore/archetypes.md#chicago-detroit)

**Ancestor:** [Hindu](../core-lore/ancestors/hindu.md)

**Tarot Card:** [The Wheel of Fortune](../core-lore/tarot-cards/the-wheel-of-fortune.md)

**Paired With:** [Ethanol](ethanol.md)

## Sources

- https://pubchem.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/compound/Sucrose
- [Sugarcane - Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sugarcane) — domestication in New Guinea (~8000 BCE), sucrose content 12-20% by weight, native to Southeast Asia
- [History of sugar - Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/History_of_sugar) — crystallization process developed in India (~350 CE), Arab traders spreading sugar production, European colonial sugar plantations
- [Sugar plantations in the Caribbean - Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sugar_plantations_in_the_Caribbean) — colonial plantation system and transatlantic slave trade
- [Sucrose - Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sucrose) — molecular formula C12H22O11, disaccharide structure
- [A short review on sugarcane: its domestication - PMC](https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC9483297/) — Saccharum officinarum domesticated from S. robustum in New Guinea

## Miberas with this Drug

════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════
SECTION: DRUG: Syrian Rue
Source: drugs-detailed/syrian-rue.md
════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════

# Syrian Rue

## Effects & Properties

**Effects:** Mild sedation, relaxation; used traditionally for its antidepressant,
anxiolytic, and antimicrobial properties.

**Natural Occurrence:** Native to arid and semi-arid regions of the
Middle East, Central Asia, and the Mediterranean, Syrian Rue is used in traditional medicine for
mood disorders, digestive issues, and as an abortifacient (though unsafe). In rituals, it is
combined with DMT-containing plants to potentiate psychedelic experiences. Recreationally, it is
used in ayahuasca analogs or as a standalone sedative.
**Appearance:** Syrian rue has small divided
green leaves, white to yellow flowers, and small round seed capsules. Dried seeds are brown to
black, spherical, and bitter.

## History

Syrian rue (Peganum harmala) has been used for at least 3,000 years across the Middle East, Central Asia, and North Africa, where it holds deep spiritual significance in Zoroastrian, Islamic, and Sufi traditions as a protective herb burned as incense (espand) to ward off the evil eye. The plant contains the MAO-inhibiting alkaloids harmine and harmaline, which were originally named "telepathine" when first isolated from Banisteriopsis caapi in the early 20th century. In the modern psychedelic community, Syrian rue gained popularity from the 1990s onward as an accessible MAO inhibitor for creating "anahuasca" or "pharmahuasca" brews, serving as a substitute for the South American Banisteriopsis caapi vine.

## Connections

**Archetype:** [Freetekno](../core-lore/archetypes.md#freetekno)

**Ancestor:** [Sufi](../core-lore/ancestors/sufis.md)

**Tarot Card:** [The Hierophant](../core-lore/tarot-cards/the-hierophant.md)

**Paired With:** [Iproniazid](iproniazid.md)

## Sources

- https://erowid.org/plants/syrian_rue/syrian_rue.shtml
- https://pubchem.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/compound/Harmine
- https://www.drugs.com/npp/syrian-rue.html
- [Peganum harmala - Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Peganum_harmala)
- [Harmala alkaloid - Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Harmala_alkaloid)
- [Harmine - Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Harmine)
- [Pharmacological and therapeutic effects of Peganum harmala and its main alkaloids - PMC](https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC3841998/)
