SECTION: DRUG: Tabernaemontana
Source: drugs-detailed/tabernaemontana.md
════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════

# Tabernaemontana

## Effects & Properties

**Effects:** Mild psychoactive properties, calming and stimulant effects,
depending on preparation and species. May cause lowered blood pressure, reduced heart rate,
and mild sedation on lower doses.

**Natural Occurrence:** Found in species like Tabernaemontana
divaricata (widely distributed in Asia), Tabernaemontana pandacaqui (Southeast Asia, Pacific
Islands), and Tabernaemontana africana (Africa). It is used in traditional medicine for fever, pain,
and snakebites. Some species are used in rituals for their sedative or psychoactive effects.
**Appearance:** The plants typically have
glossy green leaves, white or cream-colored flowers, and woody roots or bark. Dried root bark
or leaves appear as brown to reddish-brown fibrous material, often ground into powder before
usage.

## History

Tabernaemontana species have been used in traditional medicine across Africa, South America, and Southeast Asia for centuries, with various species employed for treating pain, fever, infections, and snakebites. The genus was named by French botanist Charles Plumier in honor of the 16th-century German herbalist Jakob Theodor von Bergzabern (Latinized as Tabernaemontanus). In the Bwiti tradition of Gabon and Cameroon, certain Tabernaemontana species are used alongside Tabernanthe iboga in ritual contexts, and modern pharmacological research has identified numerous bioactive alkaloids with potential applications in treating neurodegenerative diseases and addiction.

## Connections

**Archetype:** [Freetekno](../core-lore/archetypes.md#freetekno)

**Ancestor:** [Gabon](../core-lore/ancestors/gabon.md)

**Tarot Card:** [The Chariot](../core-lore/tarot-cards/the-chariot.md)

**Paired With:** [Ibogaine](ibogaine.md)

## Sources

- https://www.erowid.org/plants/tabernaemontana/tabernaemontana.shtml
- https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tabernaemontana
- [Jacobus Theodorus Tabernaemontanus - Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jacobus_Theodorus_Tabernaemontanus) — Jakob Theodor von Bergzabern, 16th-century German herbalist for whom the genus is named
- [Major Bioactive Alkaloids and Biological Activities of Tabernaemontana Species (PMC)](https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC7915066/) — bioactive alkaloids, antimicrobial, anticholinesterase, antineurodegenerative activities
- [Ethnobotany and ethnopharmacology of Tabernaemontana divaricata (PubMed)](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/18577786/) — traditional medicine uses for fever, pain, snakebites
- [New Monoterpenoid Indole Alkaloids from Tabernaemontana crassa Inhibit beta-Amyloid42 Production (MDPI)](https://www.mdpi.com/1422-0067/24/2/1487) — neurodegenerative disease research, Alzheimer pathways

════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════
SECTION: DRUG: Tea
Source: drugs-detailed/tea.md
════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════

# Tea

## Effects & Properties

**Effects:** Enhanced alertness, improved focus, mild euphoria, and reduced
sleepiness. It can improve cognitive performance and reaction time in low to moderate doses
(50-200mg). Physically it can increase heart rate, elevate blood pressure, mild diuresis, and in
some cases jitteriness or tremors.

**Natural Occurrence:** Caffeine is synthesized by plants as a
secondary metabolite to protect against insects and pathogens. It is present in seeds, leaves,
and fruits, with concentrations varying by species and environmental factors.

- Coffee beans contain 1-2% caffeine by weight.

- Tea leaves contain 2-5% caffeine varying by type.

- Cocoa beans contain small amounts of caffeine alongside theobromine.

- Found also in other plants such as kola nuts, guarana, and yerba mate.
**Appearance:** In coffee beans, it is part of a
dark brown, roasted seed matrix; in tea it is in dried green or black leaves, in guarana it is in
reddish seeds. These forms are not pure caffeine but contain it as a component.

## History

Tea drinking originated in China, traditionally attributed to Emperor Shen Nung in 2737 BCE, though historical evidence firmly places tea culture in the Yunnan province by at least the 3rd century CE. Tea became central to Chinese, Japanese, and Korean cultural practice, with Japanese tea ceremony (chado) developing into a refined art form from the 15th century onward under the influence of Zen Buddhism. The British East India Company's tea trade transformed global geopolitics, contributing to the Opium Wars with China and the American Revolution, making tea one of the most historically consequential psychoactive substances.

## Connections

**Archetype:** [Milady](../core-lore/archetypes.md#milady)

**Ancestor:** [Chinese](../core-lore/ancestors/chinese.md), [japanese](../core-lore/ancestors/japanese.md)

**Tarot Card:** [Knight of Pentacles](../core-lore/tarot-cards/knight-of-pentacles.md)

**Paired With:** [Caffeine](caffeine.md)

## Sources

- https://www.erowid.org/chemicals/caffeine/caffeine.shtml
- https://www.britannica.com/science/caffeine
- https://pubchem.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/compound/Caffeine
- [History of tea - Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/History_of_tea)
- [History of tea in China - Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/History_of_tea_in_China)
- [Japanese tea ceremony - Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Japanese_tea_ceremony)
- [Boston Tea Party - Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Boston_Tea_Party)
- [Opium Wars - Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Opium_Wars)
- [East India Company - Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/East_India_Company)

════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════
SECTION: DRUG: Testosterone
Source: drugs-detailed/testosterone.md
════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════

# Testosterone

## Effects & Properties

**Effects:** Promotes male secondary sexual characteristics like facial hair,
deep voice, muscle and bone growth, and libido. Testosterone can also enhance mood,
confidence, and aggression in some individuals. Side effects include acne, hair loss, increased
aggression, and mood swings.

**Natural Occurrence:** In humans and animals, it is synthesized
primarily in the testes for men and ovaries for women. In mammals, testosterone regulates
sexual differentiation, reproduction, and physical development. It also influences behavior such
as aggression and mating.
**Appearance:** Testosterone is not visible in
the body, existing in trace amounts in blood and tissues. It is extracted synthetically from
cholesterol or plant sterols.

## History

Testosterone was first isolated and synthesized in 1935 independently by Adolf Butenandt in Germany and Leopold Ruzicka in Switzerland, both of whom received the Nobel Prize for their work on sex hormones. Its anabolic properties were quickly exploited, with Soviet Olympic athletes using synthetic testosterone for performance enhancement by the 1950s, sparking the modern era of doping in sports. Testosterone replacement therapy became increasingly mainstream in the late 20th and early 21st centuries, and the hormone has become a cultural symbol of masculinity, performance optimization, and the biohacking movement.

## Connections

**Archetype:** [Milady](../core-lore/archetypes.md#milady)

**Ancestor:** [Hindu](../core-lore/ancestors/hindu.md)

**Tarot Card:** [The Emperor](../core-lore/tarot-cards/the-emperor.md)

**Paired With:** [Ashwagandha](ashwagandha.md)

## Sources

- https://pubchem.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/compound/Testosterone
- https://www.drugs.com/mtm/testosterone-topical.html
- [Testosterone - Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Testosterone) — molecular formula C19H28O2, synthesis by Butenandt and Ruzicka (1935), secondary sexual characteristics, physiological role
- [Leopold Ruzicka - Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Leopold_Ru%C5%BEi%C4%8Dka) — 1939 Nobel Prize in Chemistry for testosterone synthesis
- [Nobel Prize in Chemistry 1939 (nobelprize.org)](https://www.nobelprize.org/prizes/chemistry/1939/ceremony-speech/) — Butenandt and Ruzicka Nobel Prize award
- [Doping at the Olympic Games - Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Doping_at_the_Olympic_Games) — Soviet testosterone use in 1950s athletics
- [Doping in sport and its spread to at-risk populations (PMC)](https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC2219897/) — history of testosterone doping in Soviet Olympic programs
- [Androgen replacement therapy - Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Androgen_replacement_therapy) — testosterone replacement therapy history

════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════
SECTION: DRUG: Thc Edibles
Source: drugs-detailed/thc-edibles.md
════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════

# THC Edibles

## Effects & Properties

**Effects:** Intoxicant, stimulant, psychedelic, depressant.

**Natural Occurrence:** Cannabis produces psychoactive
cannabinoid chemicals such as THC and CBD. It is the most widely used (still mostly) illegal
psychoactive and has a long history of medicinal, recreational, and industrial use. The fibrous
stalks of the plant are used to produce clothing and rope. Its legal status is rapidly changing in
the US and around the world from top contraband to tolerated mind-alterant alongside alcohol
and caffeine.
- Cannabis sativa is a tall plant, generally between 8-12 feet. The leaves have long thin
fingers and are light green. The more equatorial varieties have more yellow pigments to
protect the plant from intense light. Sativa buds are long and thin and turn red as they
mature in a warm environment. In cooler environments the buds may be slightly purple.

- Cannabis indica, is a short plant, generally between 3-6 feet and its leaves have short
broad fingers. The leaves are generally dark green, sometimes tinged with purple. As
they near maturity the leaves may become significantly more purple.

- Cannabis ruderalis features large seeds, short weedy plants between 4-6 feet tall and a
lower level of THC than sativas or indicas.

## History

Cannabis-infused edibles have ancient roots, with the earliest known preparation being the Indian drink bhang, documented in Vedic texts around 1000 BCE and still consumed today during the Hindu festival of Holi. Hashish-based confections (majoun) were popular across the Arab world and were brought to Western literary attention by the Club des Hashischins in 1840s Paris, attended by writers like Baudelaire and Dumas. The modern THC edible market exploded with cannabis legalization in US states beginning with Colorado and Washington in 2012, creating a multibillion-dollar industry of precisely dosed gummies, chocolates, and beverages.

## Connections

**Archetype:** [Chicago Detroit](../core-lore/archetypes.md#chicago-detroit)

**Ancestor:** [Hindu](../core-lore/ancestors/hindu.md)

**Tarot Card:** [Eight of Cups](../core-lore/tarot-cards/eight-of-cups.md)

**Paired With:** [Bhang](bhang.md)

## Sources

- https://www.erowid.org/plants/cannabis/cannabis.shtml
- https://www.erowid.org/plants/cannabis/cannabis_info6.shtml
- [Tetrahydrocannabinol - Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tetrahydrocannabinol)
- [Tetrahydrocannabinol - PubChem (CID 16078)](https://pubchem.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/compound/Tetrahydrocannabinol)
- [Bhang - Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bhang)
- [Cannabis in India - Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cannabis_in_India)
- [Club des Hashischins - Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Club_des_Hashischins)
- [Legalization of cannabis in the United States - Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Timeline_of_cannabis_laws_in_the_United_States)

════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════
SECTION: DRUG: Tobacco
Source: drugs-detailed/tobacco.md
════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════

# Tobacco

## Effects & Properties

**Effects:** Stimulation / relaxation, short-term use may enhance memory and
attention. Addiction upon long-term usage.

**Natural Occurrence:** Native to the Americas, tobacco has a long
history of use as a a shamanic inebriant and stimulant. Nicotine is a naturally occurring
stimulant found in tobacco (Nicotiana spp.) and other solanaceous plants. At room temperature,
it is only oily liquid. As a constituent of tobacco, it has been used for many centuries in the
Americas and Australia, and is now sold in a variety of common products worldwide.
**Appearance:** Annual or bi-annual growing
1-3 meters tall with large sticky leaves.

## History

Tobacco has been cultivated and used by Indigenous peoples of the Americas for at least 8,000 years, serving as one of the most sacred plants in Native American spiritual practice, used for prayer, offerings, and ceremonial pipes. After Columbus brought tobacco to Europe in the late 15th century, it spread globally with extraordinary speed, becoming a major colonial cash crop that shaped the economies of Virginia, the Caribbean, and beyond. In India, tobacco was adopted into cultural practices including bidi smoking and hookah use, and by the 20th century, tobacco-related diseases were recognized as the leading preventable cause of death worldwide.

## Connections

**Archetype:** [Chicago Detroit](../core-lore/archetypes.md#chicago-detroit)

**Ancestor:** [Hindu](../core-lore/ancestors/hindu.md)

**Tarot Card:** [Two of Cups](../core-lore/tarot-cards/two-of-cups.md)

**Paired With:** [Nicotine](nicotine.md)

## Sources

- https://www.erowid.org/plants/tobacco/tobacco.shtml
- https://www.erowid.org/chemicals/nicotine/nicotine.shtml
- [Tobacco - Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tobacco) — Nicotiana genus, Solanaceae family, cultivation history
- [History of tobacco - Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/History_of_tobacco) — 8,000+ years of cultivation in the Americas, Columbus and European introduction
- [Nicotine - Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nicotine) — molecular formula C10H14N2, alkaloid properties, Solanaceae plant family
- [Nicotine | C10H14N2 (PubChem)](https://pubchem.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/compound/Nicotine) — chemical identity and properties
- [Tobacco (WHO Fact Sheet)](https://www.who.int/news-room/fact-sheets/detail/tobacco) — leading preventable cause of death worldwide
- [Earliest evidence for human use of tobacco in the Pleistocene Americas (PubMed)](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/34635825/) — archaeological evidence of ancient tobacco use

════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════
SECTION: DRUG: Weed
Source: drugs-detailed/weed.md
════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════

# Weed

## Effects & Properties

**Effects:** Intoxicant, stimulant, psychedelic, depressant.

**Natural Occurrence:** Cannabis produces psychoactive
cannabinoid chemicals such as THC and CBD. It is the most widely used (still mostly) illegal
psychoactive and has a long history of medicinal, recreational, and industrial use. The fibrous
stalks of the plant are used to produce clothing and rope. Its legal status is rapidly changing in
the US and around the world from top contraband to tolerated mind-alterant alongside alcohol
and caffeine.
- Cannabis sativa is a tall plant, generally between 8-12 feet. The leaves have long thin
fingers and are light green. The more equatorial varieties have more yellow pigments to
protect the plant from intense light. Sativa buds are long and thin and turn red as they
mature in a warm environment. In cooler environments the buds may be slightly purple.

- Cannabis indica, is a short plant, generally between 3-6 feet and its leaves have short
broad fingers. The leaves are generally dark green, sometimes tinged with purple. As
they near maturity the leaves may become significantly more purple.

- Cannabis ruderalis features large seeds, short weedy plants between 4-6 feet tall and a
lower level of THC than sativas or indicas.

## History

Cannabis has been cultivated for at least 5,000 years, with early evidence of psychoactive use in Central Asia and ancient China, where it appeared in the pharmacopoeia of Emperor Shen Nung around 2737 BCE. It spread through India, the Middle East, and Africa before arriving in the Americas via colonial trade routes. Cannabis became a symbol of Rastafarian spirituality in Jamaica from the 1930s onward, fueled the hippie counterculture of the 1960s, and remains one of the most widely used psychoactive substances globally, with legalization accelerating in the 21st century.

## Connections

**Archetype:** [Chicago Detroit](../core-lore/archetypes.md#chicago-detroit)

**Ancestor:** [Rastafarians](../core-lore/ancestors/rastafarians.md)

**Tarot Card:** [Nine of Cups](../core-lore/tarot-cards/nine-of-cups.md)

**Paired With:** [Weed](weed.md)

## Sources

- https://www.erowid.org/plants/cannabis/cannabis.shtml
- https://www.erowid.org/plants/cannabis/cannabis_info6.shtml
- [Tetrahydrocannabinol - Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tetrahydrocannabinol)
- [Cannabis - Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cannabis)
- [History of cannabis - Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/History_of_cannabis)
- [Cannabis ruderalis - Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cannabis_ruderalis)
- [Rastafari - Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rastafari)
- [Tetrahydrocannabinol | C21H30O2 - PubChem](https://pubchem.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/compound/Tetrahydrocannabinol)

════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════
SECTION: DRUG: Xanax
Source: drugs-detailed/xanax.md
════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════

# Xanax

## Effects & Properties

**Effects:** Induces calmness, relaxation, and mild sedation. At higher doses
can cause drowsiness, euphoria, or a sense of detachment. Physically it reduces muscle
tension, slows reaction times, and in some cases invokes dizziness or coordination impairment.
It may also cause dry mouth or mild nausea.

**Natural Occurrence:** Xanax does not occur naturally.

## History

Alprazolam (Xanax) was patented by Upjohn (now part of Pfizer) in 1971 and approved by the FDA in 1981 as the first benzodiazepine specifically indicated for panic disorder. It quickly became one of the most prescribed psychiatric medications in the United States, reflecting the era's growing recognition of anxiety disorders. By the 2010s, Xanax had become a cultural phenomenon in hip-hop and SoundCloud rap ("Xanax music"), and its recreational abuse as a "downer" in party and rave contexts has contributed to a broader benzodiazepine crisis.

## Connections

**Archetype:** [Freetekno](../core-lore/archetypes.md#freetekno)

**Ancestor:** [Hindu](../core-lore/ancestors/hindu.md)

**Tarot Card:** [Two of Swords](../core-lore/tarot-cards/two-of-swords.md)

**Paired With:** [Mandrake](mandrake.md)

## Sources

- https://pubchem.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/compound/Alprazolam
- https://www.drugs.com/alprazolam.html
- https://medlineplus.gov/druginfo/meds/a684001.html
- [Alprazolam - Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alprazolam)
- [Alprazolam - Britannica](https://www.britannica.com/science/alprazolam)
- [Benzodiazepine - Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Benzodiazepine)

════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════
SECTION: DRUG: Yohimbe
Source: drugs-detailed/yohimbe.md
════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════

# Yohimbe

## Effects & Properties

**Effects:** Mild stimulation, increased alertness, and heightened arousal.
May enhance mood and energy.

**Natural Occurrence:** Traditionally, yohimbe bark is used in
African medicine for sexual enhancement, energy, and fever treatment. Native to Central and
West Africa, Yohimbe contains Yohimbine in its bark.
**Appearance:** Yohimbe has dark green
leaves, small yellowish flowers, and grayish-brown bark. Dried Yohimbe bark appears as
reddish-brown to dark brown strips or powder with bitter, earthy odor.

## History

Yohimbe bark has been used for centuries by the Bantu-speaking peoples of West and Central Africa, particularly in Cameroon, Nigeria, and Gabon, as an aphrodisiac and stimulant consumed during extended courtship rituals and hunting expeditions. The active alkaloid yohimbine was first isolated by German chemist Adolph Spiegel in 1896, and it became one of the first pharmacologically studied aphrodisiacs. In modern times, yohimbine has been marketed as a natural supplement for sexual dysfunction and athletic performance, and it was the only FDA-approved treatment for erectile dysfunction before the advent of sildenafil (Viagra) in 1998.

## Connections

**Archetype:** [Chicago Detroit](../core-lore/archetypes.md#chicago-detroit)

**Ancestor:** [Gabon](../core-lore/ancestors/gabon.md)


## Sources

- https://erowid.org/plants/yohimbe/yohimbe.shtml
- https://pubchem.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/compound/Yohimbine
- https://www.drugs.com/npp/yohimbe.html
- https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Yohimbine
- [Corynanthe johimbe - Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Corynanthe_johimbe)
- [A literature perspective on the pharmacological applications of yohimbine - PMC](https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC9590431/)

- [Yohimbine as a treatment for erectile dysfunction: A systematic review and meta-analysis - PMC](https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC9612744/)
